BIOS.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.Undergraduate research under the guidance of a faculty member for first years and sophomores or for students with no previous undergraduate-level research experience.

BIOS.name: Undergraduate Research
BIOS.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.Undergraduate research under the guidance of a faculty member for first years and sophomores or for students with no previous undergraduate-level research experience.

BIOS.name: Special Topics
BIOS.description: Lecture course in current special topics in biological sciences. Topics will vary from year to year.

BIOS.name: Survey of Medicine
BIOS.description: Content focuses on scientific social and cultural aspects of illness how perceptions and behavior influence disease concept and fundamental aspects of medical diagnosis and treatment.

BIOS.name: Ecology & Evolution: An Australian Perspective
BIOS.description: Evolution and ecology of Australian ecosystems including rainforests open woodlands coastal habitats conservation of endangered ecosystems. Earns Biology technical credit. Research project required.

BIOS.name: Microbiology
BIOS.description: Basic biology of bacteria fungi algae and viruses with emphasis on bacteriology.

BIOS.name: Microbiology Lab
BIOS.description: Fundamental laboratory techniques in microbiology.

BIOS.name: Cell and Molecular Biology
BIOS.description: An introduction to the structure and function of cells and their organelles with emphasis on eucaryotic cellular and molecular processes.

BIOS.name: Cell and Molecular Biology Lab
BIOS.description: An introduction to experimental methods of cell and molecular biology research that will cover some fundamental topics of cell biology.

BIOS.name: Evolutionary Biology
BIOS.description: A comprehensive overview of evolutionary biology including processes (e.g. natural selection genetic drift) and resulting patterns (e.g. genome organization phylogeny and the fossil record).

BIOS.name: Fundamentals of Human Anatomy
BIOS.description: Detailed study of human body structures using a regional and systems approach.  Emphasis is placed on structural relationships and the integration of body systems.

BIOS.name: Laboratory in Human Anatomy
BIOS.description: A detailed hands-on study of human structure using high resolution models specialized specimens and dissection of selected mammalian organs and tissues.

BIOS.name: Human Physiology
BIOS.description: Students will explore the function and adaptation of the human body emphasizing neuromuscular cardio-respiratory gastrointestinal endocrine and urinary systems to maintain homeostasis and human health.

BIOS.name: Physiology Laboratory
BIOS.description: Course focuses on non-invasive human experiments supplemented with in vitro tissues experiments to explore fundamental physiological concepts and learn basic methods of physiological measurements.

BIOS.name: Special Topics
BIOS.description: Lecture course in current special topics in biological sciences. Topics will vary from year to year.

BIOS.name: Protein Biology
BIOS.description: Biological view of proteins including protein biosynthesis processing modification folding trafficking interactions degradation natural and directed evolution assembly diseases amyloids prions and protein-based inheritance.

BIOS.name: Cancer Biology and Biotechnology
BIOS.description: This course covers basic concepts of cancer biology and new technologies that are being developed to understand detect treat and prevent cancer.

BIOS.name: Exercise Physiology
BIOS.description: Physiology of human movement with emphasis on metabolic cardiorespiratory and musculoskeletal aspects associated topics include body composition thermoregulation and ergogenic aids.

BIOS.name: Genomics and Applied Bioinformatics
BIOS.description: Retrieval and analysis of biological sequence gene expression and proteomics data from public databases and other sources applying standard bioinformatics tools to investigate biological questions.

BIOS.name: Kinesiological Basis of Human Movement
BIOS.description: This course teaches principles related to the biomechanics energetics and motor control of movement as it applies to human and animal movement rehabilitation and sports performance.

BIOS.name: Biological Oceanography
BIOS.description: An introduction to the major biological processes in the ocean including primary production elemental cycling food webs and fisheries.

BIOS.name: Molecular Evolution
BIOS.description: Evolutionary processes at molecular level organization of genomes and genetic systems. Students will read and present up-to-date research articles in various topics in molecular evolution.

BIOS.name: Ion Channels
BIOS.description: We will examine the basic biophysical properties structure-function relationships physiological regulation pathology and pharmacological manipulation of ion channels with heavy reliance on recent literature.

BIOS.name: Medical Microbiology
BIOS.description: Advanced study of bacteria protozoa fungi and viruses that cause human diseases emphasis on epidemiology mechanisms of disease causation prevention and treatment.

BIOS.name: Human Neuroanatomy
BIOS.description: The purpose of this course is to learn the anatomical makeup of the human nervous system.  In this course we will closely examine details of central and peripheral neuroanatomy with links to function.  As well comparisons with non-human vertebrate neuroanatomy will be made.

BIOS.name: Experimental Design and Statistical Methods in Biological Sciences
BIOS.description: Introductory course on experimental design hypothesis testing and basic statistical techniques commonly applied in biosciences research. Exercises based on statistical software packages.

BIOS.name: Microbial Ecology
BIOS.description: Advanced studies of microbial ecosystems the specific roles of bacteria in maintaining ecological balance and the evolution of the ecosystem in response to changing environments.

BIOS.name: Marine Ecology
BIOS.description: An overview of the physical forces and biotic interactions structuring marine communities and of the major threats to these communities.

BIOS.name: Microbial Physiology
BIOS.description: Study of the physiology of growth and metabolic activities of microorganisms.

BIOS.name: Population Dynamics
BIOS.description: Students will examine the ecological factors that affect dynamics regulation and evolution of natural populations emphasizing the connections with mathematical models genetics and ecology.

BIOS.name: Behavioral Biology
BIOS.description: Students learn to convey the importance of research findings in the biological sciences and to critically evaluate research results through discussions and scientific presentations..

BIOS.name: Developmental Biology
BIOS.description: Investigation of cell differentiation and development using the tools of molecular genetics and cell biology.

BIOS.name: Behavioral Biology
BIOS.description: An introduction to the study of the principles of behavior of all kinds of organisms from microbes to mammals.

BIOS.name: Evolutionary Developmental Biology – How to Build an Organism
BIOS.description: This course teaches students how the process of development from embryo to adult impacts evolutionary diversity and human health.

BIOS.name: Drug Discovery
BIOS.description: You will learn about the drug discovery process by identifying a disease and disease target  and then design a therapy to treat the disease.

BIOS.name: Epigenetics,  Stem Cells, and Development
BIOS.description: This course will introduce the basic concepts and mechanisms in epigenetics covering topics ranging from stem cell reprogramming organismal development social behaviors to human diseases.

BIOS.name: Community Ecology
BIOS.description: An advanced ecology course that covers classic and contemporary concepts patterns and processes in the field of community ecology.

BIOS.name: Health Genes Society
BIOS.description: Capstone project based investigation of the roles that genes and culture play in shaping health including an introduction to personalized medicine.

BIOS.name: Human Evolutionary Genomics
BIOS.description: An advanced course where students will discuss primary literature and use computational tools to investigate how evolution has shaped global patterns of human genetic variation.

BIOS.name: Human Motor Control
BIOS.description: Course provides in-depth review of biomechanics and neurophysiology of human motion and discusses how human movements are planned executed and corrected by the nervous system.

BIOS.name: Genetics of Complex Human Traits and Diseases
BIOS.description: Introduction to the genetics and evolution of complex human traits focusing on contemporary approaches to understanding susceptibility to malignant metabolic immune and psychological diseases.

BIOS.name: Origin of complex life: from cells to societies
BIOS.description: This course examines the evolutionary origins of complex life. We will examine the history of life on Earth and evolutionary process through which complexity arises.

BIOS.name: RNA Biology and Biotechnology
BIOS.description: This course covers fundamental concepts of RNA biology as well as state-of-the-art biotechnologies that make use of RNA.

BIOS.name: Immunology
BIOS.description: A survey of modern immunology and its applications.

BIOS.name: Research Project Lab
BIOS.description: Experience in designing implementing and communicating a biology research project and practical training in modern approaches for biological research.

BIOS.name: Molecular Biology of Microbes: Disease, Nature, and Biotechnology
BIOS.description: Molecular genetics of bacteria with an emphasis on experimental approaches regulatory mechanisms on disease-causing and environmental bacteria and biotechnology applications derived from microbes.

BIOS.name: Aquatic Chemical Ecology
BIOS.description: The course focuses on understanding the chemical mechanisms of aquatic signaling and the cascading effects on population regulation community organization and ecosystem function.

BIOS.name: Bioethics
BIOS.description: This course examines important bioethical issues in research policy medicine and the environment in light of ethical theory and the process of scientific inquiry.

BIOS.name: Eukaryotic Molecular Genetics
BIOS.description: Topics in molecular genetics including genetic engineering techniques gene expression and regulation gene structure stability and evolution with emphasis on eukaryotic organisms.

BIOS.name: Independent Research Project

BIOL.description: Students will examine the ecological factors that affect dynamics regulation and evolution of natural populations emphasizing the connections with mathematical models genetics and ecology. Credit will not be awarded for both BIOL4428 and BIOL6428.

BIOL.name: Plant Physiology
BIOL.description: Chemical transformation in photosynthesis photophysiology and water relationships organic nutrition and effects of hormones on growth and development of plants.

BIOL.name: General Animal Physiology I
BIOL.description: Systems physiology including nerves muscles kidney digestion circulation endocrinology reproduction and respiration.

BIOL.name: Communicating Biological Research
BIOL.description: Students learn to convey the importance of research findings in the biological sciences and to critically evaluate research results through discussions and scientific presentations. Credit will not be awarded for both BIOL 4450 and BIOL4460.

BIOL.name: Developmental Biology
BIOL.description: Investigations of cell differentiation and development using the tools of molecular genetics and cell biology.

BIOL.name: Behavioral Biology
BIOL.description: An introduction to the study of the principles of behavior of all kinds of organisms from microbes to mammals.

BIOL.name: Biophysics
BIOL.description: Biophysical aspects of nucleic acids proteins and their interactions.

BIOL.name: Evolutionary Developmental Biology-How to Build an Organism
BIOL.description: This course teaches students how the process of development from embryo to adult impacts evolutionary diversity and human health.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL4480 and BIOL6480.

BIOL.name: Genetics of Complex Human Traits and Diseases
BIOL.description: Introduction to the genetics and evolution of complex human traits focusing on contemporary approaches to understanding susceptibility to malignant metabolic immune and psychological diseases.

BIOL.name: Immunology and Immunochemistry
BIOL.description: A survey of modern immunology and its applications.

BIOL.name: Research Project Lab
BIOL.description: Experience in designing implementing and communicating a biology research project and practical training in modern approaches for biological research.

BIOL.name: Molecular Biology of Microbes: Disease, Nature, and Biotechnology
BIOL.description: Molecular genetics of bacteria with an emphasis on experimental approaches regulatory mechanisms in disease-causing and environmental bacteria and biotechnology applications derived from microbes. Credit not awarded for both BIOL4607 and BIOL4608 or BIOL4607 and BIOL6608 or BIOL4607 and BIOL6607.

BIOL.name: Prokaryotic Molecular Genetics
BIOL.description: The molecular genetics of bacteria and their viruses with emphasis in the organization replication expression transfer and experimental manipulation of prokaryotic genes and genomes. Credit not allowed for both BIOL 4220 and BIOL4608 or BIOL4608 and BIOL4607 or BIOL4608 and BIOL6607.

BIOL.name: Aquatic Chemical Ecology
BIOL.description: Focuses on understanding the chemical mechanisms of aquatic signaling and the cascading effects on population regulation community organization and ecosystem function.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL4620 and BIOL6620.

BIOL.name: Bioethics
BIOL.description: This course will examine the process of scientific inquiry and the ethical implications of research in the biological sciences.

BIOL.name: Foundations of Bioethics
BIOL.description: This course examines important bioethical issues in research policy medicine and the environment in light of ethical theory and the process of scientific inquiry. Credit not awarded for both BIOL4651 and BIOL4650.

BIOL.name: Eukaryotic Molecular Genetics
BIOL.description: Topics in molecular genetics including genetic engineering techniques gene expression and regulation genetic structure stability and evolution with emphasis on eukaryotic organisms.

BIOL.name: Independent Research Project
BIOL.description: Independent research with proposal and manuscript writing conducted with the guidance of a faculty member.

BIOL.name: Intern Assistantship(Undergraduate Internship for Pay)
BIOL.description: Biology Undergraduate Internship for pay for juniors and seniors by permit only. The internship experience must at a unit or agency approved by the School of Biology.

BIOL.name: Undergraduate Internship(Undergraduate Internship for Academic Credit)
BIOL.description: Biology Undergraduate Internship for credit for juniors and seniors by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Biology.

BIOL.name: Biology Undergraduate Teaching Assistantship
BIOL.description: Biology teaching carried out under the guidance of a faculty member.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL4696 and BIOL4697.

BIOL.name: Biology Undergraduate Teaching Experience
BIOL.description: An introduction to teaching biology for undergraduate teaching assistants with a focus on effective teaching active engagement of students and development of innovative classroom activities.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL4696 and BIOL4697.

BIOL.name: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
BIOL.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BIOL.name: Undergraduate Research
BIOL.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BIOL.name: Biologically Inspired Design
BIOL.description: We examine evolutionary adaptation as a source for engineering design inspiration utilizing principles of scaling adaptability and robust multifunctionality that characterize biological systems.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL4740 and (ISYE4740 or PTFE 4740 or MSE4740 or ME4740).

BIOL.name: Microbial Symbiosis & Microbiomes
BIOL.description: This course explores how symbiotic interactions with microbes affect the biology of other organisms focusing extensively on the beneficial microbes native to the human body.

BIOL.name: Signaling Molecules
BIOL.description: The diversity of chemical signals between organisms and their structural specifications will be presented along with chemical and biological methods for isolating signaling molecules.

BIOL.name: Introductory Neuroscience
BIOL.description: Goals are to understand the components of the nervous system and their functional interactions and appreciate the complexity of higher order brain functions and pathways. Crosslisted with BMED4752.

BIOL.name: Mathematical Biology
BIOL.description: An introduction to practical applications of mathematical models to help unravel the underlying mechanisms involved in biological processes. Crosslisted with MATH4755.

BIOL.name: Special Topics
BIOL.description: This designation enables the School of Biology to provide new lecture courses dealing with areas of current interest in biological science.

BIOL.name: Special Problems
BIOL.description: Research problem in biology under supervision of a faculty member. To be offered any term with credit to be arranged. Seven hours (four hours technical electives + three hours free elective) are the maximum credits allowed toward the Bachelor of Science in Biology degree.

BIOL.name: Special Problems
BIOL.description: Research problem in biology under supervision of a faculty member.  To be offered any quarter with credit to be arranged. Seven hours (four hours technical electives + three hours free electives) are the maximum credits allowed toward the Bachelor of Science in Biology degree.

BIOL.name: Special Problems
BIOL.description: Research problem in biology under supervision of a faculty member.  To be offered any quarter with credit to be arranged.  Seven hours (four hours technical electives + three hours free electives) are the maximum credits allowed toward the Bachelor of Science in Biology degree.

BIOL.name: Special Problems
BIOL.description: Research problem in biology under supervision of a faculty member.  To be offered any quarter with credit to be arranged.  Seven hours ( four hours technical electives + three hours free electives) are the maximum credits allowed toward the Bachelor of Science in Biology degree.

BIOL.name: Special Problems
BIOL.description: Special problem in biology under supervision of a faculty member.  To be offered any quarter with credit to be arranged.  Seven hours (four hours technical electives + three hours free electives) are the maximum credits allowed toward the Bachelor of Science in Biology degree.

BIOL.name: Honors Undergraduate Research Thesis
BIOL.description: Writing and submission of an Undergraduate Research Thesis describing research accomplishments with a Georgia Tech faculty member. For a thesis conducted without a Biological Sciences faculty member the instructor of record and a second reader from the School must both approve the thesis contains sufficient biological content.

BIOL.name: Genomics and Applied Bioinformatics
BIOL.description: Retrieval and analysis of biological sequence gene expression and proteomics data from public databases and other sources applying standard bioinformatics tools to investigate biological questions.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL6150 and BIOL4150.

BIOL.name: Biological Oceanography
BIOL.description: An introduction to the major biological processes in the ocean including primary production elemental cycling food webs and fisheries.

BIOL.name: Microbial Ecology
BIOL.description: Advanced studies of microbial ecosystems the specific roles of bacteria in maintaining ecological balance and the evolution of the ecosystem in response to changing environments.

BIOL.name: Marine Ecology
BIOL.description: An overview of the ecological and evolutionary patterns processes and mechanisms affecting the organization structure and function of a broad variety of marine communities.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL6417 and BIOL4417.

BIOL.name: Microbial Physiology
BIOL.description: Study of the physiology of growth and metabolic activities of microorganisms.

BIOL.name: Theoretical Ecology
BIOL.description: Theoretical foundations of ecology from the population to the community and ecosystem levels.

BIOL.name: Population Dynamics
BIOL.description: Students will examine the ecological factors that affect dynamics regulation and evolution of natural populations emphasizing the connections with mathematical models genetics and ecology. Credit will not be awarded for both BIOL6428 and BIOL4428.

BIOL.name: Methods in Molecular Biophysics
BIOL.description: An introduction to biophysical methods that are employed to study biological macromolecules and their interaction to gain understanding of how they function.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL6478 and BIOL4478.

BIOL.name: Evolutionary Developmental Biology-How to Build an Organism
BIOL.description: This course teaches students how the process of development from embryo to adult impacts evolutionary diversity and human health.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL6480 and BIOL4480.

BIOL.name: Immunology
BIOL.description: A survey of modern immunology and its applications with emphasis on immunological methods used in molecular and cell biological research.

BIOL.name: Evolution
BIOL.description: An introduction to evolutionary patterns and processes including the history of life phylogenetics population genetics quantitative genetics molecular evolution and other important topics in evolutionary biology.

BIOL.name: Molecular Biology of Microbes: Disease, Nature, and Biotechnology
BIOL.description: Molecular genetics of bacteria with an emphasis on experimental approaches regulatory mechanisms in disease-causing and environmental bacteria and biotechnology applications derived from microbes. Credit will not be awarded for both BIOL6607 and BIOL4607 BIOL4608 or BIOL6608.

BIOL.name: Advanced Microbial Genetics
BIOL.description: Molecular mechanisms of bacterial and plasmid genetic processes.  Topics covered include genome organization DNA replication transcription and translation. Credit will not be awarded for both BIOL6608 and BIOL4607 or BIOL6608 and BIOL6607.

BIOL.name: Advanced Microbial Physiology
BIOL.description: Advanced studies of selected aspects of the physiololgy of prokaryotic and eukaryotic microorganisms.

BIOL.name: Aquatic Chemical Ecology
BIOL.description: The course focuses on understanding the chemical mechanisms of aquatic signaling and the cascading effects on population regulation community organization and ecosystem function.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL6620 and BIOL4620.

BIOL.name: Experiments in Aquatic Chemical Signaling
BIOL.description: A full-time commitment to student-originated but faculty-guided interdisciplinary research in aquatic chemical signaling using field lab and flume facilities at Skidaway Institution of Oceanography on the coast.

BIOL.name: Physiological Ecology
BIOL.description: Study of the basic physiological processes and systems in vertebrates and invertebrates.  Comparative study on how these systems are adapted for specific environments and functions.

BIOL.name: Aquatic Toxicology
BIOL.description: Study of the biological effects of toxicants on aquatic organisms-mechanisms of toxicity biotransformation toxicity tests ecological risk assessment.

BIOL.name: Advanced Microbial Ecology
BIOL.description: Advanced studies of selected aspects of the ecology of prokaryotic and eukaryotic organisms.

BIOL.name: Environmental Microbial Genomics
BIOL.description: To introduce advanced concepts and principles of contemporary environmental microbiological research and assosciated bioinformatics techniques through representative examples from recent literature.

BIOL.name: Foundations of Quantitative Biosciences
BIOL.description: Introduction to quantitative methods and logic that enable key advances in understanding living systems spanning molecules cells organisms and biomes.

BIOL.name: Discovery of Signaling Molecules
BIOL.description: The diversity of chemical signals between organisms and their structural specificities will be presented along with chemical and biological methods for isolating signaling molecules.  Crosslisted with CEE6756 and CHEM6756.

BIOL.name: Geomicrobiology
BIOL.description: Interactions between microorganisms and the geosphere microbial energetics and genetics geochemical controls on microbial diversity and activity.  Crosslisted with EAS6765.

BIOL.name: Foundations in Molecular and Cell Biology
BIOL.description: The goal of this course is to provide new students with fundamental knowledge in the general areas of prokaryotic and eukaryotic molecular biology biochemistry structural biology and bioinformatics.

BIOL.name: Advanced Cell Biology
BIOL.description: Current topics in eukarytotic cell biology including membrane functions intracellular sorting and compartmentalization cell signaling cell cycle cytoskeleton cell adhesion motility and current experimental approaches.

BIOL.name: Cancer Biology and Technology
BIOL.description: This course covers the major concepts of cancer biology as well as to state-of-the-art technologies that are being applied to cancer research detection and treatment.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL7015 and BIOL4015.

BIOL.name: Bioinformatics
BIOL.description: Introduction to mathematical statistical and computer methods of nucleic acid and protein sequence analysis and interpretation. Algorithms for gene finding protein structure and function prediction constructing phylogenetic trees.

BIOL.name: Advanced Sensory Ecology
BIOL.description: A quantitative analysis of how organisms of all kinds obtain information about their environment and how they use it to guide locomotions.

BIOL.name: Macromolecular Modeling
BIOL.description: Principles and practices in the use of molecular mechanics methods (minimization molecular dynamics) to study structure-function relationships in biological macromolecules.

BIOL.name: Molecular Evolution
BIOL.description: Evolutionary processes at the molecular level organizations of genomes and genetic systems. Students will read and present up-to-date research articles in various topics in molecular evolution.

BIOL.name: Programming for Bioinformatics
BIOL.description: This active-learning project-based course provides a rigorous introduction to scientific computing for bioinformatics including Linux utilities shell scripting and bioinformatics programming.

BIOL.name: Computational Genomics
BIOL.description: In this active learning class students will learn to convert sequence information into knowledge through the use of computational genomics tools applications and databases.

BIOL.name: Eucaryotic Molecular Genetics
BIOL.description: Topics in molecular genetics of eukaryotic organisms including gene structure and expression protein processing and folding genome stability and molecular evolution.

BIOL.name: Advances in Microbiology
BIOL.description: Topics of current interest in microbial physiology applied microbiology microbial ecology and medical microbiology.

BIOL.name: Advances in Bacteriology
BIOL.description: Topics of current interest in the physiology and ecology of bacteria and applications to practical problems.

BIOL.name: Advances in Ecology
BIOL.description: Topics of current interest in the general areas of population growth and limitation and the structure and stability of ecosystems.

BIOL.name: Advances in Environmental Biology
BIOL.description: Topics of current interest in environmental biology.

BIOL.name: Advances in Molecular Biology
BIOL.description: Topics of current interest in molecular biology.

BIOL.name: Advances in Genetics
BIOL.description: Topics of current interest in genetics.

BIOL.name: Integrative Biology Seminar
BIOL.description: A reading and discussion course structured around the School of Biology weekly seminar.

BIOL.name: Seminar
BIOL.description: Presentation of research seminar.

BIOL.name: Seminar
BIOL.description: Weekly seminars on current research presented by various scientists in the field of biology.

BIOL.name: Seminar
BIOL.description: Weekly seminars on current research presented by various scientists in the field of biology.

BIOL.name: Signals in the Sea Seminar
BIOL.description: Students and invited authorities in the field will present seminars and lead discussions focused on currently emerging topics in aquatic chemical ecology and signaling.

BIOL.name: Integrative Approaches to Biological Systems
BIOL.description: This course will investigate using samples from the literature and faculty research the general principles of biological systems from gene expression circuits to ecological communities.

BIOL.name: Tools of Science Seminar
BIOL.description: This course addresses issues important to all successful scientists and engineers such as research ethics collaborations between industry academics and government women and minorities in science balancing research teaching and service writing editing and reviewing presentations job interviews time management speaking to the public and media and scientific and university politics.

BIOL.name: Epigenetics,  Stem Cells, and Development
BIOL.description: This course will introduce the basic concepts and mechanisms in epigenetics covering topics ranging from stem cell reprogramming organismal development social behaviors to human diseases.

BIOL.name: Community Ecology
BIOL.description: An advanced ecology course that covers classic and contemporary concepts patterns and processes in the field of community ecology.

BIOL.name: Human Evolutionary Genomics
BIOL.description: An advanced course where students will discuss primary literature and use computational tools to investigate how evolution has shaped global patterns of human genetic variation.

BIOL.name: Origin of complex life: from cells to societies
BIOL.description: This course examines the evolutionary origins of complex life. We will examine the history of life on Earth and evolutionary process through which complexity arises.

BIOL.name: RNA Biology and Bitechnology
BIOL.description: The purpose of this course is to introduce students (graduate and upper level undergraduate) to the fundamental concepts of RNA biology and to state-of-the-art biotechnologies that use RNA for medical and industrial applications.

BIOL.name: Microbial Symbiosis & Microbiomes
BIOL.description: This course explores how symbiotic interactions with microbes affect the biology of other organisms focusing extensively on the beneficial microbes native to the human body.

BMEJ.description: For GT PKU and Emory students during terms when they are not taking other GT courses.  Placeholder course.

BMED.name: Introduction to Biomedical Engineering
BMED.description: An introduction to the field of biomedical engineering with an emphasis on career preparation.

BMED.name: Problems in Biomedical Engineering I
BMED.description: Biomedical engineering problems from industrial and clinical applications are addressed and solved in small groups using problem-based learning methodologies.

BMED.name: Introduction to Bioengineering
BMED.description: An introduction to the field of bioengineering including the application of engineering principles and methods to problems in biology and medicine the integration of engineering with biology and the emerging industrial opportunities.  Crosslisted with AE CHE ECE ME and MSE1750.

BMED.description: A study of material and energy balances applied to problems in biomedical engineering.

BMED.name: Problems in Biomedical Engineering
BMED.description: Biomedical engineering problems from industrial and clinical applications are addressed and solved in small groups using problem-based learning methodologies. Credit will not be awarded for both BMED2250 and BMED1300.

BMED.name: Problems in Biomedical Engineering II
BMED.description: Biomedical engineering problems from industrial and clinical applications are addressed and solved in small groups using problem-based learning methods.

BMED.name: Intro to Biomedical Engineering Design
BMED.description: In small teams students will apply problem-based learning and human centered design to reverse engineer analyze and redesign medical devices. Credit will not be awareded for both BMED2310 and BMED2300.

BMED.name: Introduction to Bioengineering Statistics
BMED.description: Introduction to statistical modeling and data analysis in bioscientific and bioengineering applications. Topics include estimation testing regression and experimental design.

BMED.name: Systems Physiology
BMED.description: An introduction to human physiology emphasizing biomedical engineering aproaches to the understanding of basic organ function disease states and medical intervention.

BMED.name: Introduction to Biomedical Data Science and Engineering
BMED.description: Practical/hands-on experience in performing biomedical-related data processing/computation/analysis with a variety of computer tools platforms and applications.

BMED.name: Quantitative Engineering Physiology Laboratory I
BMED.description: A hands-on lab providing an active learning team environment to reinforce selected engineering principles of physiology emphasizing a quantitative model-oriented approach to physiological systems.

BMED.name: Biotransport
BMED.description: Fundamental principles of fluid heat and mass transfer with particular emphasis on physiological and biomedical systems.

BMED.name: Biotransport
BMED.description: Fundamental principles of fluid heat and mass transfer with particular emphasis on physiological and biomedical systems. Credit will not be awarded for both BMED3310 and BMED3300.

BMED.name: Introduction to Biomechanics
BMED.description: An introduction to the basic concepts and methods in biomechanics including statistics and the mechanics of biomaterials.  The biomedical applications of mechanics will be illustrated.

BMED.name: Introduction to Biomechanics
BMED.description: Introduces concepts and approaches for biomedical deformation and dynamics problems using the application of simple models from statics mechanics of materials kinematics and dynamics.

BMED.name: Biomedical Sensors and Instrumentation
BMED.description: A study of basic concepts and design of electronic sensors and instrumentation used in biomedical measurements. Standard clinical measurement techniques will also be examined.

BMED.name: Biomedical Systems and Modeling
BMED.description: Basic concepts modeling tools and analysis techniques for the study of biochemical bioelectrical and biomedical systems.

BMED.name: Biomedical Systems and Modeling
BMED.description: Introduction of computational systems biology including the modeling process various types of models standard analysis and simulation of systems and applications in real-world biological systems. Credit will not be awarded for both BMED3520 and BMED3510.

BMED.name: Physiology of Cellular and Molecular Systems
BMED.description: In depth cell and molecular physiology focused on cellular responses to stimuli including cell organization/ reorganization membrane transport/kinetics cell signaling/ molecular biology mechanobiology and energy requirements.

BMED.name: Quantitative Engineering Physiology Laboratory II
BMED.description: This lab provides an active learning team environment incorporating common cell/molecular biology techniques to reinforce selected engineering principles in an in vitro cell culture setting.

BMED.name: Special Topics
BMED.description: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering.

BMED.name: The Art of Telling Your Story
BMED.description: Students will create a professional portfolio and develop the ability to pitch themselves to an audience to prepare themselves to begin their professional careers.

BMED.name: Neuroengineering Fundamentals
BMED.description: Lab and lecture on current topics in Neuroengineering including electrophysiology clinical and diagnostic neuroengineering neural prosthetics sensory-motor integration neuromorphic VLSI neurodynamics and neurorobotics.

BMED.name: Biological Networks and Genomics
BMED.description: Introduction to modeling of biological networks involved in gene regulation cell signaling and metabolism. Mathematical modeling of cellular processes such as gene expression using genomic data.

BMED.name: Cell and Tissue Engineering Laboratory
BMED.description: The principles of cell and tissue engineering will be presented as a laboratory course to give students a hands-on experience.  Cell engineering topics include receptor/ligand interactions cell cycle/metabolism cell adhesion cellular mechanics cell signal transduction and cell transfection.  Tissue engineering topics include applications biomaterials/scaffolds and cells for reparative medicine bioreactors and bioprocessing functional assessment in vivo issues.

BMED.name: Senior Design Project I
BMED.description: Team-oriented major design project in biomedical engineering incorporating engineering standards and realistic design constraints.  Credit not allowed for BMED4600 and BMED4603 (or BMED4601).

BMED.name: Senior Design Project II
BMED.description: Team-oriented major design project in biomedical engineering incorporating engineering standards and realistic design constraints.  Credit not allowed for both BMED4601 and BMED4603 (or BMED4600).

BMED.name: Capstone Design
BMED.description: Team-oriented design project in biomedical engineering incorporating engineering standards and realistic design constraints.  Includes introduction to relevant regulatory intellectual property and business management topics.

BMED.name: Advanced Design
BMED.description: Continuation of a team-oriented design experience initiated in BMED4602 Capstone Design.  Includes more advanced relevant regulatory. intellectual property and business management topics.  Credit not allowed for both BMED4603 and BMED4600 (or BMED4601).

BMED.name: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
BMED.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BMED.name: Undergraduate Research
BMED.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BMED.name: Medical Robotics
BMED.description: An interdisciplinary course focusing on fundamental understanding of robot kinematics and dynamics as well as the design development and evaluation of a medical robotic system.

BMED.name: Biologically Inspired Design
BMED.description: We examine evolutionary adaptation as a source for engineering design inspiration utilizing principles of scaling adaptability and robust multifunctionality that characterize biological systems.

BMED.name: Diagnostic Imaging Physics
BMED.description: Physics and image formation methods for conventional X-ray digital X-ray CT nuclear medicine and magnetic resonance and ultrasound imaging.  Crosslisted with MP4750 and NRE4750.

BMED.name: Introduction to Biomaterials
BMED.description: Introduction to different classes of biomaterials (polymers metals ceramics) and physiological responses to biomaterial implantation. Topics include material properties host response and biomaterial characterization techniques. Crosslisted with MSE4751.

BMED.name: Introductory Neuroscience
BMED.description: Goals are to understand the components of the nervous system and their functional interactions and appreciate the complexity of higher order brain functions and pathways. Crosslisted with BIOL4752.

BMED.name: Biofluid Mechanics
BMED.description: Introduction to the study of blood flow in the cardiovascular system. Emphasis on modeling and the potential of flow studies for clinical research application. Crosslisted with AE CHE and ME4757.

BMED.name: Biosolid Mechanics
BMED.description: The mechanics of living tissue e.g. arteries skin heart muscle ligament tendon cartilage and bone. Constitutive equations and some simple mechanical models. Mechanics of cells.  Applications. Crosslisted with AE CHE and ME4758.

BMED.name: Drug Design, Development and Delivery
BMED.description: Introduction to the pharmaceutical development process including design of new drugs synthesis and manufacturing issues and methods for delivery into the body. Includes student presentations. Crosslisted with CHEM and CHBE4765.

BMED.name: Biomedical Instrumentation
BMED.description: A study of medical instrumentation from a systems viewpoint. Pertinent physiological and electro-physiological concepts will be covered.  Credit not allowed for both BMED4781 and (CHE 4781 or ME4781 or CHBE4781 or ECE4781).

BMED.name: Biosystems Analysis
BMED.description: Analytical methods for modeling biological systems including white-noise protocols for characterizing nonlinear systems. Crosslisted with CHE ECE and ME4782.

BMED.name: Introduction to Medical Image Processing
BMED.description: A study of mathematical methods used in medical image acquisition and processing. Concepts algorithms and methods associated with acquisition processing and display of two- and three-dimensional medical imaged are studied. Crosslisted with ECE4783.

BMED.name: Engineering Electrophysiology
BMED.description: Basic concepts of electrophysiology from an engineering perspective. Functionality of relevant organs and systems instrumentation tools which monitor electrophysiology function. Crosslisted with ECE4784.

BMED.name: Analytical Methods for Biomedical Engineering
BMED.description: Basic analytical approaches to solve mathematical problems involved in biomedical engineering applications. Course focuses on ordinary and partial differential equations and on integral transform methods.

BMED.name: Systems Physiology
BMED.description: Regulation of physiological functions in the cardio-respiratory-renal musculoskeletal and gastrointestinal systems and their interactions with the neural endocrine and immune systems.

BMED.name: Magnetic Resonance Imaging
BMED.description: This course covers the basic physics and engineering principles advanced techniques and major applications of magnetic resonance imaging.

BMED.name: Fundamentals of Biomedical Innovation and Development Processes
BMED.description: Key steps multiple stakeholders and interdependencies in the design and commercialization process for medical products.

BMED.name: BioID Clinical Literacy and Experience
BMED.description: Education in interfacing with medical healthcare professionals medical terminology on-site clinical observations needs-finding case analysis creating design solutions for improved methods products and procedures.

BMED.name: Medical Markets and Clinical Specialties
BMED.description: Introduction to medical device and biologics industries interdependencies of commercial companies vendors and suppliers required for development commercialization and sales of products and equipment.

BMED.name: Financial Planning for Development Projects
BMED.description: Finance planning for development projects including costing forecasting time value of money breakeven analysis return on investment analysis capital budgeting risk and return working capital management.

BMED.name: Product Planning and Project Management
BMED.description: Strategy and analysis techniques to evaluate and manage new product innovations product improvements and product line extensions in context of an entitys mission and goals.

BMED.name: Professional Communications for Biomedical Innovation and Development
BMED.description: Techniques and practice of effective oral presentations project/grant proposal writing technical and project report writing to support medical device engineering design and business.

BMED.name: Medical Device Regulatory Requirements
BMED.description: FDA Regulations for medical devices including clearance-approval pathways to commercialization Quality Systems Regulations and ISO Standards for medical devices in the European Economic Community.

BMED.name: BioID Team Masters Project I
BMED.description: Team project to address an unmet medical need and develop an innovative solution including the engineering design document package and proof-of-concept prototyhpe.

BMED.name: BioID Masters Project II
BMED.description: Teams will construct prototypes for Course I biomedical device project solution conduct and analyze performance testing prepare FDA 510(k) submission and prepare project commercialization plan.

BMED.name: Machine Learning in Biosciences
BMED.description: Introduces machine learning concepts and methods including supervised and unsupervised learning dimension reduction and visualization. Topics are accompanied by bioinformatics and systems biology applications.

BMED.name: Biostatistics
BMED.description: An introduction to fundamental ideas and techniques in Biostatistics with an emphasis on conceptual understanding and on the analysis of real data sets.

BMED.name: Rational Design of Biomaterials
BMED.description: The goal of this course is to give graduate students the ability to rationally design new biomaterials by integrating organic chemistry concepts with molecular biology.

BMED.name: Rational Design of Biomaterials Lab
BMED.description: The goal of this course is to teach students the laboratory skills needed to design and synthesize new biomaterials.

BMED.name: Biotransport
BMED.description: This graduate level course covers the analysis of fluid flow phenomena in the human body cardiovasculature respiratory system and other organ systems.

BMED.name: Materials Science of Cellular Components
BMED.description: Addresses structure-property relationship of cellular components.  Credit not allowed for both BMED6730 and MSE6730.

BMED.name: Medical Robotics
BMED.description: This interdisciplinary course focuses on a fundamental understanding of robot kinematics and dynamics as well as the design development and evaluation of a medical robotic system.

BMED.name: Living System Modeling & Analysis
BMED.description: The purpose of this course is to introduce graduate students to living system models as pre-clinical test beds for a wide variety of biotechnologies.

BMED.name: Tissue Mechanics
BMED.description: Structure-function relationships and constitutive models for a variety of biological tissues with an emphasis on understanding the mechanical behaviors of normal and pathological tissues. Credit not given for both BMED/ME 6783 and BMED/ME6743. Crosslisted with ME6743.

BMED.name: Principles of Management for Engineers
BMED.description: The course will provide an introduction to selected topics needed to be successful in the technology industries. Cannot count toward major area requirements in M.S. or Ph.D. programs of study.

BMED.name: Information Processing Models in Neural Systems
BMED.description: This course will examine top down modeling approaches for sensorineural systems where an optimal computational principle used in engineering (e.g. information theory Bayesian inference control theory) explains observed information processing.

BMED.name: Drug Design, Development and Delivery
BMED.description: Introduction to the pharmaceutical development process including design of new drugs synthesis and manufacturing issues and methods of delivery into the body. Includes student presentations.  Crosslisted with BMED6765 and CHBE6765.

BMED.name: Biomaterials: Structure and Function
BMED.description: Structure-function relationships of biomaterials and biomaterial characterization will be covered. Materials for medial implants tissue engineering biosensing imaging and drug delivery will be covered. Crosslisted with CHE ME and MSE6774.

BMED.name: Advanced Biomaterials
BMED.description: Advanced topics of biomaterials performance and engineering including biointerfaces host reactions to materials and bio-inspired/smart-materials strategies. Crosslisted with CHE ME and MSE6777.

BMED.name: Bioprocess Engineering
BMED.description: Study of enzymes and microbial and mammalian cells for production of biochemicals and protein therapeutics in bioreactors downstream separation and purification integrated view of bioprocesses. Crosslisted with CHE 6779.

BMED.name: Medical Image Processing
BMED.description: A study of methods for enhancing analyzing interpreting and visualizing information from two- and three-dimensional data obtained from a variety of medical imaging modalities. Crosslisted with ECE and CS6780.

BMED.name: Cellular Engineering
BMED.description: Engineering analysis of cellular systems.  Crosslisted with CHE and ME6782.

BMED.name: Cardiovascular Biomechanics
BMED.description: Mechanical analysis of the cardiovascular system emphasizing the normal and pathologic function in relation to clinical cardiovascular medicine.  Crosslisted with CHE and ME 6784.

BMED.name: Medical Imaging Systems
BMED.description: A study of the principles and design of medical imaging systems such as X-ray ultrasound nuclear medicine and nuclear magnetic resonance. Crosslisted with ECE6786.

BMED.name: Quantitative Electrophysiology
BMED.description: A quantitative presentation of electrophysiological systems in biological organisms emphasizing the electrical properties and modeling of neural and cardiac cells and systems.  Crosslisted with PHYS and ECE6787.

BMED.name: Technology Ventures
BMED.description: Team discussion and case studies in biomedical engineering technology transfer including licensing financial capital safety and efficacy studies clinical trials and strategic planning.  Crosslisted with ECE CHE ME and MGT6789.

BMED.name: Information Processing Models in Neural Systems
BMED.description: Examines top-down modeling approaches for sensorineural systems where optimal computational principles used in engineering(e.g. information theory Bayesian inference control theory) explain observed information processing.

BMED.name: Systems Pathophysiology
BMED.description: Overview of human pathophysiology from a quantitative perspective.  A brief introduction to the application of quantitative models to the understanding of biological systems.  Crosslisted with CHE ECE and ME6793.

BMED.name: Tissue Engineering
BMED.description: Biological engineering and medical issues in developing tissue engineered constructs. Emphasis in the integration of these disciplines at a basic molecular and cell biology level.  Crosslisted with CHE and ME6794.

BMED.name: Legal Issues in Technology Transfer
BMED.description: Study and analysis of U.S. law as it applies to the patenting and licensing processes. Crosslisted with CHE ME and MGT6799.

BMED.name: Biomedical Engineering Seminar
BMED.description: Graduate students of the Biomedical Engineering department (all programs) participate in seminars involving current research projects presented by faculty and invited speakers.

BMED.name: Teaching Practicum I
BMED.description: This course provides discipline-specific training that addresses intellectual problems and teaching strategies from the perspective of the discipline.  Credit not allowed for both BMED7002 and BMED 8696.

BMED.name: Teaching Practicum II
BMED.description: This course provides discipline-specific training that addresses intellectual problems and teaching strategies from the perspective of the discipline.  Credit not allowed for both BMED7003 and BMED 8697.

BMED.name: Teaching & Research Practicum I
BMED.description: This course provides the practicial framework for understanding challenges faced during teaching research and academic life. This course includes topical materials required for BME RCR requirements.

BMED.name: Teaching & Research Practicum II
BMED.description: This course provides the practical framework for understanding challenges faced during teaching research and academic life.

BMED.name: Integrative Core: Introduction to Modeling and Experimentation in Biomedical Engineering
BMED.description: An introduction to how engineers approach problems - via conceptual models that are then used to create wet lab models and in silico models.

BMED.name: Integrative Core: Experimental Design-Measurements at the Right Spatial and Temporal Scales
BMED.description: This integrative core course focuses on the design of experiments to answer scientific questions with an emphasis on the spatial and temporal scales of measurements.

BMED.name: Integrative Core: Problem Solving with Computational Models
BMED.description: An introduction to computational model methodologies for complex biomedical/biological systems.  Emphasis is placed on developing well-posed scientific hypotheses through the use of simulations.

BMED.name: Advanced Seminar: Biomaterials & Regenerative Medicine
BMED.description: This course is intended to promote critical review of the State-of-the-art biomaterial technologies to identify knowledge gaps that must be overcome to further biomaterials development.

BMED.name: Advanced Seminar: Cardiovascular Biology & Biomechanics
BMED.description: To review current topics in cardiovascular engineering biology and diseases through critical literature review.  In addition each student will develop and present a Proposal by the end of the class.

BMED.name: Advanced Seminar: Cellular & Biomolecular Engineering
BMED.description: This seminar course illustrates the development of micro- and nano-scale engineering approaches for studies of biomolecules and cells and their applications to medicine.

BMED.name: Stem Cell Engineering
BMED.description: Fundamentals for the application of analytical engineering approaches to the quantitative study of stem cell biology and translation into cell therapies and diagnostics.

BMED.name: Introduction to Multiscale Analysis in Systems
BMED.description: The class explores modeling analyses spanning multiple levels of biological organization at different resolutions of detail.  Emphasis is placed on control in complex biological systems.

BMED.name: Mathematical Models in Biology & Medicine
BMED.description: The course introduces the student to a representative set of models that elucidate the nature of biological and medical phenomena.

BMED.name: Biochemical Systems Analysis
BMED.description: The course introduces BME students interested in mathematical modeling and systems biology to the computational analysis of metabolic and other dynamic systems in biology.

BMED.name: Advanced Seminar: Neuroengineering and Neuropathology
BMED.description: Current issues in neuroengineering.  Focus is placed on neuropathological complexity across cellular and organ level scales through literature reading discussion and independent study.

BMED.name: Quantitative Neuroscience
BMED.description: A quantitative presentation of neural signal processing and information coding emphasizing the circuitry of sensory and motor pathways of the brain.

BMED.name: Robotics Professional Preparation
BMED.description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local  visiting speakers. Program introduction. Technical resume preparation. GT Robotics labs  resources.

BMED.name: Robotics Professional Preparation 2
BMED.description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local  visiting speakers. Selecting and applying for Internship. Developing capstone project proposal. Public speaking practice and preparation.

BMED.name: Robotics Professional Preparation 3
BMED.description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local  visiting speakers. Interview preparation  career search. Technical report writing and presentation.

BMED.name: Introduction to Robotics Research
BMED.description: Familiarizes students with the core of robotics mechanics control perception AI and autonomy.  Provides an introduction to the mathematical tools required in robotics research. Cross-listed with AE7785 ECE7785 and CS7785.

BMED.name: Robotics Internship
BMED.description: Graduate Internship at a partner company GTRI or a GT Robotics lab.

BMED.name: Robotics Capstone Project
BMED.description: Teams or individuals apply the knowledge and skills acquired throughout the MS program to a faculty supervised robotics project.

BMED.name: Multidisciplinary Robotics Research I
BMED.description: Multidisciplinary research course supervised by two robotics faculty from different schools participating in the robotics Ph.D. program. Cross-listed with AE CS and ECE8750.

BMED.name: Multidisciplinary Robotics Research II
BMED.description: Continuation of BMED8750 (Multidisciplinary Robotics Research I). Cros-listed with AE CS and ECE8751.

BC.name: Construction Technology I
BC.description: An introduction to the planning and physical development process for the construction of projects of residential and light construction scale.

BC.name: Construction Technology II
BC.description: A continuation of Construction Technology I with an emphasis on large- scale and high-rise building i.e. commercial building construction.

BC.name: Construction Seminar
BC.description: Provides an introduction to the construction industry with emphasis on exploring career opportunities in construction.

BC.name: Construction Materials and Methods
BC.description: The course will cover the planning and physical development process for the construction of residential commercial and heavy/industrial projects.

BC.name: Construction Plans and Estimates
BC.description: Course focuses on reading and accessing project drawing information and estimating quantities for pricing of materials labor subcontracts and equipment.

BC.name: Construction Safety
BC.description: This course introduces the core elements of an effective safety and health management system in a construction project and describes the application of OSHA standards.

BC.name: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
BC.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BC.name: Undergraduate Research
BC.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BC.name: Construction Cost Management
BC.description: Introduction to cost principles and cost analysis of construction projects including classification of work quantity survey techniques construction operation costs and bid proposals.

BC.name: Construction Law
BC.description: Legal aspects of construction contracts bonds insurance and bidding. Owner architect contractor and subcontractor relationships.

BC.name: Real Estate and Construction Finance and Accounting
BC.description: General introduction to the financing of construction and real estate development projects. Emphasis on financing requirements activities sources and uses.

BC.name: Project Management I
BC.description: This course will offer construction planning and management techniques for project design and construction with a focus on different scheduling methods and their use.

BC.name: Construction Mechanics
BC.description: An introductory course to the evaluation of behavior of buildings the properties of structural materials and the behavior of load-resisting members.

BC.name: History of Construction Industry
BC.description: Addresses how todays construction industry is organized and its particular characteristics how it evolved from early times and where it may be heading in the future.

BC.name: Building Information Modeling for Multi-disciplinary Integration
BC.description: This course introduces students to BIM and the changes it has been causing to the traditional design planning management construction facility management and contracting practices.

BC.name: Trends & Pol For Res Dev
BC.description: An overview of development in the United States current trends in residential development and the impact of external factors on residential development.  This course is designed to help Building Construction students understand how their development impacts the social environment and quality of life of the community.

BC.name: Community Dsgn & Constr
BC.description: An overview of the principles of smart growth livable communities and new urbanism and how these principles are implemented in the process from design to construction and marketing.

BC.name: Intg Design Constr & Dev
BC.description: A study of contemporary examples of an integrated approach to design construction and development.  Course involves real-world project analysis from multiple points of view.

BC.name: Construction Management Project
BC.description: This class is the application of course materials covered throughout the Certificate in Construction Management to an actual construction project with a simulated business construct.

BC.name: Project Management II
BC.description: This course covers practical project management technology and tools for this approach and the  required management skills for successful execution of projects.

BC.name: Value Engineering and Building Economics
BC.description: First part is an introduction to principles and methodology.  Second part is an introduction to economic principles and theories and how to apply the concepts and methods of building economics.

BC.name: Building Structural Analysis
BC.description: Emphasis being placed on the practical design and construction of structural elements.  The course includes basic design principles with a heavy emphasis on constructability and buildability.

BC.name: Senior Capstone Project
BC.description: A senior construction project that  includes redevelopment analysis and feasibility study project development and construction.

BC.name: Construction Marketing
BC.description: Methods of construction marketing and business development. Innovative computer applications verbal skills development professional strategies market segmentation and buyer behavior.

BC.name: Laboratory for Sustainable Design and Construction
BC.description: The goal of the laboratory is to teach students a comprehensive sustainable design and construction information system and a program of real-world hands-on projects.

BC.name: Entrepreneurship in Construction
BC.description: Basics of construction business risk assessment looking for construction opportunities capital investment computerized construction business and business failures.

BC.name: Mechanical, Electrical and Plumbing Systems for Construction Managers
BC.description: The course will cover the fundamentals of design selection installation commissioning and maintenance of mechanical electrical and plumbing systems.  Credit not allowed for both BC4672 and BC4670.

BC.name: Professional Internship
BC.description: Students work for a professional architecture/engineering/ construction company in which they learn first-hand about the construction industry.

BC.name: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
BC.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BC.name: Undergraduate Research
BC.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BC.name: Construction Management
BC.description: An accelerated-pace course designed to provide a basic understanding of fundamental topics including planning budgeting estimation scheduling and project close out.

BC.name: Green Construction
BC.description: This course focuses on the means methods strategies and technologies to improve the energy efficiency and performance of buildings and to reduce the environmental impact of buildings.

BC.name: Residential Construction and Property Management
BC.description: A course designed to orient students to the basics of apartment management and includes the business functions of marketing leasing and financing.

BC.name: Best Practices in Multi-Family Property
BC.description: A course designed to provide students with a broad range of the best practices related to the management of all types of multi-family residential property.

BC.name: Real Estate Development and Construction
BC.description: Provides an overview of the real estate development process as it pertains to construction development including trends and current issues.

BC.name: Special Topics
BC.description: Topics of current interest in building construction.

BC.name: Issues in Sustainable Construction Technology
BC.description: Course designed to help students achieve a basic understanding of the materials used in the commercial segments in the construction industry and how these relate to sustainable construction.

BC.name: Sustainable Energy in Architecture, Engineering and Construction
BC.description: An introductory course on sustainale energy in architecture engineering and construction.  The goal of the course is to introduce students to fundamental concepts of sustainable sources of energy to power buildings and address the impact of these sources to applicable green building rating systems.

BC.name: Technology Applications in the Construction Industry
BC.description: Hands-on exploration of various present and Future technologies that can be applied in all stages of a facilities lifecycle.

BC.name: Advanced Cost Management
BC.description: Cost management and control from early project inception to completion and applications throughout the life of a facility.

BC.name: History of Construction Industry
BC.description: Addresses how todays construction industry is organized and its particular characteristics how it evolved from early times and where it may be heading in the future.

BC.name: Construction Management
BC.description: An accelerated paced course providing graduate students a basic understanding of fundamental topics including planning budgeting estimating scheduling and project closeout.

BC.name: Building Information Modeling for Multi-disciplinary Integration
BC.description: This course introduces students to BIM and the changes it has been causing to the traditional design planning management construction facility management and contracting practices. Credit will not be awarded for both BC4050 and BC6050.

BC.name: Professional Trends in Facility Management
BC.description: An introductory course covering the organizational managerial ethical and legal principles for the delivery of facility management services.  Includes contracts and risk management.

BC.name: Professional Internship
BC.description: A course in which students work for a professional architecture/engineering/construction company in which they learn first-hand about the construction industry.

BC.name: Design-Build Organization and Management
BC.description: Introduction to Design-Build (DB) as a project delivery system.  Provides information about the organization the process and the effects of DB on the industry.

BC.name: Real Estate Development and Construction
BC.description: Provides an overview of the real estate development process as it pertains to construction development including trends and current issues.

BC.name: Introduction to Construction Program Management
BC.description: Survey of the construction program management profession focusing on the comprehensive management of single and multiple building programs including pre-design design construction and post-construction activities.

BC.name: Maintenance Management of Built Assets
BC.description: This course covers the processes by which a facility and its systems are serviced and maintained during the facilitys life cycle.  Includes acquisition installation operation maintenance and disposal of built assets.

BC.name: Value Management for Integrated Facility Design and Construction
BC.description: Principles and methodology of value management analysis concepts and an examination of future values and worth criteria affecting building design construction furnishings and operations performance.

BC.name: Community Design and Development
BC.description: An overview of the principles of smart growth livable communities and new urbanism and how these principles are implemented in the process from design to construction and marketing.

BC.name: Community Dsgn & Constr
BC.description: An overview of the principles of smart growth livable communities and new urbanism and how these principles are implemented in the process from design to construction and marketing.

BC.name: Management of Pre-design Phase as Owner
BC.description: Examination of the Program Managers role and responsibilities as owner during the pre-design phase including feasibility organization financing legal entitlement planning budgeting scheduling and team selection.

BC.name: Safety and Environmental Issues
BC.description: This course covers the environmental issues related to the performance of buildings and the health and risk factors for new and existing buildings.

BC.name: Design and Construction Law
BC.description: Overview of construction law and legal issues encountered by the construction manager including U.S. laws general concepts and definitions contractor relationships and relevant case studies.

BC.name: Real Estate Policy, Trends, Ethics
BC.description: The application of market community and policy factors to create new development while professionally managing potential conflicts between these factors.

BC.name: Trends & Pol For Res Dev
BC.description: An overview of development in the United States current trends in residential development and the impact of governmental regulations on residential development. This course is designed to help Building Construction students understand how their development impacts the social environment and quality of life of the community.

BC.name: Management of Design Phase as Owner
BC.description: Examination of the Program Managers role and responsibilities as Owner during the design phase.

BC.name: Facility Planning, Project Management, and Benchmarking
BC.description: This course introduces the techniques of planning project management benchmarking and their applications to facility management.  Includes space forecasting scheduling and control of projects and benchmarking studies.

BC.name: Real Estate Asset and Income Property Management
BC.description: This course covers real estate financial management and performance topics from a decision making and strategic planning orientation for facilities management professionals.

BC.name: Design and Construction Processes for Integrated Services
BC.description: Offers a framework for use and application of design contract and performance documents for successful execution of various forms of integrated project delivery systems.

BC.name: Real Estate Development Basic Finance
BC.description: Comprehensive overview of the business model and financing methodology to analyze and produce new real estate development.

BC.name: Real Estate Production Finance
BC.description: Business model and financing process required to produce new real estate developments through an investigation of land acquisition development and construction financial management.

BC.name: Management of Construction as Owner
BC.description: Survey of construction management from the owners perspective.

BC.name: Facilities Management Financial Analysis
BC.description: This course covers real property concepts issues and topics pertinent to the facility management professional.  The topics include site selection property market analysis legal documents and land use control.

BC.name: Advanced Project Management
BC.description: A four-phased coverage of project management including organization planning and scheduling control budgeting and ending with project testing evaluation and termination.

BC.name: Residential Design and Construction
BC.description: Course will examine the application of market community and regulatory factors to single family housing design and construction construction management process required for efficient delivery.

BC.name: Leadership and Communications in Design and Construction
BC.description: Framework and guidelines for effective leadership and communications during design and construction.

BC.name: Advanced Facility Management Practices
BC.description: Students apply specific methods and procedures from core courses to actual business situations in the facility and property management industry.

BC.name: Zero Energy Housing
BC.description: Design analysis operation construction and cost feasibility of so-called zero energy houses.  Credit not allowed for both BC6731 and ARCH6731.

BC.name: Facility and Property Management Capstone
BC.description: Designed to integrate the learning from basic topics through the use of actual case studies and situations found within the facility and property management industry.

BC.name: Building Construction and Facility Management Capstone
BC.description: Application of coursework covered in the Master of Science in Building Construction and Facility Management curriculum with a stimulated business construct from different perspectives construction manager program manager or facility manager.

BC.name: Real Estate Development Capstone Project
BC.description: Formulation and exploration of a real estate development project. Topics include business plan market analysis site selection regulations finance project delivery design and engineering.

BC.name: Best Practices in Multi-Family Property
BC.description: A course designed to provide students with a broad range of the best practices related to the management of all types of multi-family residential property.

BC.name: Introduction to Residential Property Management
BC.description: A course designed to orient students to the basics of apartment management and includes the business functions of marketing leasing and financing.

BC.name: Intg Design Constr & Dev
BC.description: This course will focus on contemporary integrated approach to design construction and development.  Course involves real-world project analysis from multiple points aof view. Examples to be selected from the Atlanta region.

BC.name: The Evolution of a Deal
BC.description: Presentations and site visits conducted by developers to expose students to design program implementation financial structure and project management.

BC.name: Quantitative Methods for Construction Research
BC.description: Introductory course in graduate research in the building construction industry.  Covers types of research sampling methods and basic analysis and evaluation techniques.

BC.name: Advanced Readings in BC in Preparation for the PhD Comprehensive Examination
BC.description: This course is designed around advanced readings in research and practice for PhD students working in the building construction area.

BC.name: PhD Seminar for Students with Building Construction Emphasis
BC.description: This is an introduction to PhD-level research in Building Construction.

BC.name: Research Methodology
BC.description: Research design course that teaches the basics of creating credible scientific research plans with examples from construction related research.
