ECE.description: Introduction to random signals and processes with emphasis on applications in ECE.  Includes basic estimation theory linear prediction and statistical modeling.

ECE.name: Fundamentals of Digital Signal Processing
ECE.description: Introduction to digital signal processing. Sampling theorem discrete-time Fourier transform. Power spectrum discrete Fourier transform and the FFT algorithm Z-transform digital filter design and implementation.

ECE.name: Applications of Digital Signal Processing
ECE.description: Applications of DSP in speech image processing radar pattern recognition and adaptive filtering requiring working software implementations applied to the analysis of real signals.

ECE.name: Design Synthesis of Application-specific Signal Processors
ECE.description: Fundamentals of theory and practice of DSP chip design in VHDL. Exposure to tools and environments for chip design simulation and verification.

ECE.name: Power System Analysis and Control
ECE.description: Introduces basic concepts in electric power generation distribution system control and economic operation.

ECE.name: Power System Engineering
ECE.description: To introduce basic concepts of electric power system design encompassing protection stability and control.

ECE.name: Electric Power Quality
ECE.description: Transients and harmonics in power systems analysis methods and mitigation practices.  Causes of power quality problems and relationship to equipment susceptibility.  Credit not allowed for both ECE4325 and ECE 6340.

ECE.name: Power Electronics
ECE.description: Introduces power semiconductor devices and power electronic converters including single-phase and three-phase ac/dc rectifiers ac voltage controllers dc/dc converters and dc/ac inverters.

ECE.name: Electric Machinery Analysis
ECE.description: Advanced theory of AC machines including AC motor winding design finite element analysis induction motor design permanent magnet machine design and synchronous machine dynamics.  Credit is not allowed for both ECE4335 and ECE6335.

ECE.name: Electromagnetic and Microwave Applications
ECE.description: Presents concepts of electromagnetic fields applied to microwave circuit design and antenna radiation. Credit will not be awarded for ECE4350 and ECE3065.

ECE.name: RF-Microwave Measurement Laboratory
ECE.description: RF/microwave measurement theory and techniques. Use of state-of-the-art equipment operating into the GHz range.

ECE.name: Antenna Engineering
ECE.description: Basic theory application and design of a broad range of antennas.

ECE.name: Antenna Engineering Laboratory
ECE.description: Experimentation to develop a practical understanding of antennas and their properties.

ECE.name: Introduction to Radar and Electromagnetic Sensing
ECE.description: Introduces students to radar systems including pulsed CW CWFM and MTI radars. Other techniques for electromagnetic sensing such as radiometry and EM tagging are discussed.

ECE.name: Electromagnetic Compatibility
ECE.description: To study electromagnetic interference and susceptibility of electrical systems with application to analog and digital circuits.

ECE.name: Analog Filters
ECE.description: An introduction to the theory design techniques and applications of analog passive active and switched- capacitor filters.

ECE.name: RF Engineering I
ECE.description: Fundamentals of RF engineering. Components at high frequencies device modeling amplifiers lumped-element and microstrip impedance transformation networks S-parameter-based design of RF and microwave amplifiers.

ECE.name: RF Engineering II
ECE.description: Fundamentals learned in RF-I are employed to design the elements of radio receivers transmitters and similar systems.  Systems analysis mixers detectors power amplifiers low-noise amplifiers and oscillators are covered.

ECE.name: Digital Integrated Circuits
ECE.description: Analysis and design of bipolar and MOS digital integrated circuit families and their applications in modern electronic systems.

ECE.name: Analog Integrated Circuits
ECE.description: Analysis and design of analog ICs using analytic techniques and CAD tools. Topics include amplifiers current sources output circuits and other analog building blocks.

ECE.name: Operational Amplifier Design
ECE.description: Analysis and design techniques for utilization of integrated circuit operational amplifiers for applications in electronic systems.

ECE.name: Audio Engineering
ECE.description: Concepts of acoustics and electroacoustic modeling for the analysis and design of microphones loudspeakers and crossover networks. Methods of analysis and design of audio power amplifiers.

ECE.name: Audio Engineering Laboratory
ECE.description: A companion laboratory to ECE4445. Design analysis construction modeling and testing of circuits and systems pertaining to audio engineering.

ECE.name: Analog Circuits for Music Synthesis
ECE.description: Circuits from classic analog synthesizers nonlinear waveshapers and voltage-controlled oscillators filters and amplifier using operational transconductance amplifliers and the dynamic resistance of semiconductors.

ECE.name: Semiconductor Devices for Wireless and Fiber Communication
ECE.description: Advanced development of semiconductor device theory focusing on optoelectronic emitters detectors and high- frequency transistors to provide an understanding of devices used in communications systems.

ECE.name: IC Fabrication
ECE.description: Introduction to microelectronic processing technologies and CMOS. Includes a laboratory for fabrication/testing of MOS transistors basic CMOS circuits integrated resistors and capacitors. Credit will not be awarded for ECE4452 and ECE4752.

ECE.name: Introduction to Electronic Systems Packaging
ECE.description: Introduction to packaging technologies technology drivers electrical performance thermal management materials optoelectronics RF integration reliability system issues assembly testing.

ECE.name: Devices for Renewable Energy
ECE.description: Students study the engineering compromises operational physics and environmental impact of a variety of devices from solar cells batteries thermoelectric devices and wind generators.

ECE.name: Optical Engineering
ECE.description: Introduction to applications of geometric physical optics to engineering including optical measurements matrix methods instruments interference holography beam optics Fourier optics and diffraction.

ECE.name: Fiber Optics
ECE.description: Combined lecture-laboratory exploration of the technology of fiber optics with special emphasis on optical fiber communications systems. Credit will not be awarded for ECE4501 and ECE4502.

ECE.name: Optical Fiber Communications
ECE.description: Combined lecture-laboratory exploration of the technology of fiber optics with emphasis on optical fiber communication systems. Credit will not be awarded for ECE4502 and ECE4501.

ECE.name: Control System Design
ECE.description: Design of control algorithms using state-space methods microcontroller implementation of control algorithms and laboratory projects emphasizing motion control applications.

ECE.name: Systems and Controls I
ECE.description: Introduction to feedback control.  Root locus and bode design for SISO systems continuous and discrete. Introduction to state space formulation continuous and discrete.

ECE.name: Embedded and Hybrid Control Systems
ECE.description: Modeling analysis and design of embedded and hybrid control systems.

ECE.name: Introduction to Automation and Robotics
ECE.description: Concurrent engineering principles robotic manipulator kinematics dynamics and control applications of robots in industry medicine and other areas team projects and hands-on laboratory experience.

ECE.name: Neural Networks and Fuzzy Logic in Control
ECE.description: Principles of neural networks and fuzzy systems the MATLAB Neural Network and Fuzzy Logic Toolboxes examples from system identification classification and control laboratory experience.

ECE.name: Game Theory and Multiagent Systems
ECE.description: An introduction to game theory and its application to multiagent systems including distributed routing multivehicle control and networked systems.

ECE.name: System Theory for Communication and Control
ECE.description: Study of the basic concepts in linear system theory and numerical linear algebra with applications to communication computation control and signal processing. A unified treatment.

ECE.name: Numerical Methods for Optimization and Optimal Control
ECE.description: Algorithms for numerical optimization and optimal control Gradient-descent techniques linear programming numerical linear system solvers second-order methods of optimizing performance of dynamical systems.

ECE.name: Computational Computer Vision
ECE.description: Computational and theoretical aspects of computer vision. Application areas include robotics autonomous vehicles tracking and image-guided surgery. Includes major project.

ECE.name: Communication Systems
ECE.description: To present the fundamentals of modern digital communication systems and evaluate their performance with realistic channel models.

ECE.name: Communication Systems Laboratory
ECE.description: To examine the performance of analog and digital telecommunications systems and components. Credit will not be awarded for ECE4612 and ECE4602.

ECE.name: Network Design and Simulation
ECE.description: Introduces the principles of Monte Carlo techniques and network simulation and applies them to design issues in ATM systems.

ECE.name: Topics in Networks
ECE.description: Reviews on networking fundamentals. Latest networking technologies in wireless and wireline networks. Machine learning and data science in networks or other emerging topics. Projects included.

ECE.name: Wireless Communications
ECE.description: Cellular concept wireless propagation modeling types of digital modulation used in wireless systems diversity combining performance over fading channels and multiple access techniques.

ECE.name: Mobile and Wireless Networks
ECE.description: Basics of mobile and wireless networking. Architectures and communication protocols for wireless sensor networks wireless local area networks ad-hoc networks cellular systems WiMAX and Wireless Mesh Networks.

ECE.name: Telecommunications Systems Laboratory
ECE.description: Basic digital telecommunications systems are examined in a laboratory setting using electronic modules covering concepts such as modulation channel coding AWGN eye diagrams and BER. Credit will not be awarded for ECE4612 and ECE4602.

ECE.name: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
ECE.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

ECE.name: Undergraduate Research
ECE.description: Independent Research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

ECE.name: Laser Theory and Applications
ECE.description: Provides an introduction to the theory and applications of laser principles and related instrumentation. Emphasis is on the fundamental principles underlying laser action. Crosslisted with PHYS4751.

ECE.name: Integrated Circuit Fabrication
ECE.description: Gives students exposure to the various steps involved in the fabrication of integrated circuits and devices.  The course will include a laboratory segment in which students fabricate MOS transistors diffused resistors and MOS capacitors from a bare silicon substrate. Crosslisted with CHE 4752. Credit will not be awarded for ECE4752 and ECE4452.

ECE.name: Topics in Engineering Practice
ECE.description: Topics of current importance offered in collaboration with an approved partner of Georgia Techs Distance Learning Program. Crosslisted with ME4753.

ECE.name: Electronics Packaging Assembly, Reliability, Thermal Management, and Test
ECE.description: The course provides hands-on instruction in electronics packaging including assembly reliability thermal management and test of next-generation microsystems.  Crosslisted with ME and MSE4754.

ECE.name: Electronic Packaging Substrate Fabrication
ECE.description: This course provides hands-on instruction in basic packaging substrate fabrication techniques including interconnect design and testing dielectric deposition via formation and metallization.  Crosslisted with CHE 4755.

ECE.name: Industrial Controls and Manufacturing
ECE.description: Students are introduced to industrial controls and the fundamentals of manufacturing with hands-on experience based on lab projects using industry software and hardware for communications and control. Crosslisted with PTFE 4761.

ECE.name: Biomedical Instrumentation
ECE.description: A study of medical instrumentation from a systems viewpoint. Pertinent physiological and electro-physiological concepts will be covered. Credit not allowed for both ECE4781 and (CHE 4781 or CHBE4781 or  BMED4781 or ME4781).

ECE.name: Biosystems Analysis
ECE.description: Analytical methods for modeling biological systems including white-noise protocols for characterizing nonlinear systems. Crosslisted with BMED CHE and ME4782.

ECE.name: Introduction to Medical Image Processing
ECE.description: A study of mathematical methods used in medical acquisition and processing.  Concepts algorithms and methods associated with acquisition processing and display of two- and three-dimensional medical images are studied.  Crosslisted with BMED4783.

ECE.name: Engineering Electrophysiology
ECE.description: Basic concepts of electrophysiology from an engineering perspective. Functionality of relevant organs and systems instrumentation tools which monitor electrophysiology function. Crosslisted with BMED4784.

ECE.name: GPU Programming for Video Games
ECE.description: 3-D graphics pipelines. Physically-based rendering. Game engine architectures. GPU architectures. Graphics APIs. Vertex and pixel shader programming. Post-processing effects. Deferred rendering.

ECE.name: Special Topics
ECE.description: Special Topics in ECE.

ECE.name: Special Topics
ECE.description: Special Topics in ECE.

ECE.name: Undergraduate Research I
ECE.description: Participation in an individual or group research project under the direction of a faculty member.

ECE.name: Undergraduate Research II
ECE.description: Participation in an individual or group research project under the direction of a faculty member.

ECE.name: Advanced Computer Architecture
ECE.description: Comprehensive coverage of the architecture and system issues that confront the design of high-performance workstation/PC computer architectures with emphasis on quantitative evaluation.  Credit is not allowed for both ECE6100 and any of the following courses ECE4100 CS4290 CS6290.

ECE.name: Parallel and Distributed Computer Architecture
ECE.description: An advanced study of the critical issues and limiting factors in the design of asynchronous and synchronous parallel and distributed architectures.

ECE.name: Dependable Distributed Systems
ECE.description: Concepts theory and practice of dependable distributed systems. Techniques for tolerating hardware and software faults. Security aspects such as confidentiality availability and integrity.

ECE.name: CAD for Computer Communication Networks
ECE.description: Investigation of the methodologies and algorithms used for designing and optimizing computer/communications networks with a focus on the algorithmic aspects of network design.

ECE.name: Interconnection Networks for High-Performance Systems
ECE.description: This course teaches the fundamentals of Interconnection Networks (topology routing flow-control microarchitecture and system interface) which form the communication backbone of computer systems from on-chip many-core to HPC datacenters.

ECE.name: Automata Theory
ECE.description: The course presents a broad base of topics in modern automata and switching theory.  These elements form the essentials upon which modern digital systems are constructed.

ECE.name: Combinatorial Strategies for Engineers
ECE.description: Modern counting theory and algorithmic approaches necessary for discrete computation.

ECE.name: Advanced Programming Techniques
ECE.description: Covers a number of advanced topics in programming methods data management distributed computing and advanced algorithms used in typical engineering applications. Credit will not be awarded for ECE6122 and ECE4122.

ECE.name: Advanced VLSI Systems
ECE.description: An advanced treatment of VLSI systems analysis design and testing with emphasis on complex systems and how they are incorporated into a silicon environment.  Credit is not allowed for both ECE4130 and ECE6130.

ECE.name: Computer-aided VLSI System Design
ECE.description: Theory and practice of computer-aided VLSI digital systems design.   Logic synthesis semi-custom VLSI design high-level synthesis low-power systems and hardware/software co-design.  Individual and group projects.

ECE.name: Physical Design Automation of VLSI Systems
ECE.description: Various design automation problems in the physical design process of VLSI circuits including clustering partitioning floor planning placement routing and compaction.

ECE.name: Digital Systems in Nanometer Nodes
ECE.description: An advanced treatment of design challenges such as power variability and reliability associated with digital integrated circuits and systems in nanometer nodes.

ECE.name: Digital Systems Test
ECE.description: Introduction to the basic concepts in digital systems testing.  Advanced topics in fault modeling and simulation test pattern generation and design for testability.

ECE.name: Computational Aspects of Cyber-Physical Systems
ECE.description: Fundamental concepts foundations and methodologies for the design of high-performance cyber-physical systems including control/computing co-design.

ECE.name: Biomedical Applications of Microelectromechanical Systems
ECE.description: MEMS processing technologies design of fabrication process flows and applications of the technologies to the development of biomedical micro instrumentation and dectection methodologies.

ECE.name: Introduction to Microelectromechanical Systems
ECE.description: Introduction to Micro-Electro-Mechanical systems Microfabrication techniques including photolithography etching physical and chemical vapor deposition electroplating bonding and polymer processing.  Application to sensors and actuators.  Credit not allowed for both ECE6229 and ME6229 or CHBE6229.

ECE.name: Advanced Digital Signal Processing
ECE.description: An introduction to advanced signal processing methods that are used in a variety of applications areas.

ECE.name: Statistical Digital Signal Processing and Modeling
ECE.description: An introduction to the theory of statistical learning and practical machine learning algorithms with applications in signal processing and data analysis.

ECE.name: Digital Processing of Speech Signals
ECE.description: The application of digital signal processing to problems in speech communication. Part of this goal requires a laboratory project.

ECE.name: Digital Image Processing
ECE.description: An introduction to the theory of multidimensional signal processing and digital image processing including key applications in multimedia products and services and telecommunications.

ECE.name: Data Compression and Modeling
ECE.description: Theory and algorithms of signal encoding and decoding for data compression.  Applications in information systems digital telephony digital television and multimedia Internet.

ECE.name: Adaptive Filtering
ECE.description: Basic theory of adaptive filter design and implementation. Steepest decent LMS algorithms nonlinear adaptive filters and neural networks. Analysis of performance and applications.

ECE.name: Fundamentals of Radar Signal Processing
ECE.description: Signal modeling including radar cross section multipath and clutter. Properties of the ambiguity function and coded waveforms. Algorithms for Doppler processing detection and radar imaging.

ECE.name: Methods of Pattern Recognition with Application to Voice
ECE.description: Theory and application of pattern recognition with a special application section for automatic speech recognition and related signal processing.

ECE.name: Statistical  Natural Language Processing
ECE.description: Foundations of statistical natural language processing established for text data analysis language engineering information extraction and statistical inference. Applications using large text datasets are illustrated.

ECE.name: DSP Hardware Systems Design
ECE.description: A study of theory and practice in the design and implementation of DSP algorithms on programmable processors multiprocessors and ASICs.

ECE.name: DSP Software Systems Design
ECE.description: Specification evaluation and implementation of real-time DSP applications on embedded DSP-based environments.

ECE.name: Spatial Array Processing
ECE.description: Introduce application areas where signals are sampled over space and time.  Transfer knowledge of time-based techniques to spatial processing. Develop algorithms unique to spatial processing.

ECE.name: Cryptography & Security
ECE.description: Algebraic and number theory apporaches to cryptographic techniques information security secret key and public key encryption signature schemes hash functions message authentication and key distribution. Credit not allowed for both ECE6280 and CS6260.

ECE.name: Radar Imaging
ECE.description: An indepth study of digital signal processing methods for Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) image formation.  Methods are also applicable to sonar.

ECE.name: Harmonic Analysis for Signal Processing
ECE.description: Explores the role of sparse representations in signal processing. Specific topics include frame decompositions approximation theory inverse problems imaging and compressed sensing.

ECE.name: Power Systems Control and Operation
ECE.description: Introduction to methods used in the real-time operation and control of power systems as well as to the hardware and software technology of energy management systems (EMS). Credit will not be awarded for both ECE6320 and ECEP6301.

ECE.name: Power System Stability
ECE.description: Techniques for stability analysis of electric power systems and applications of these methods.

ECE.name: Power System Planning and Reliability
ECE.description: To introduce basic concepts as well as analysis and optimization techniques underlying reliability assessment of electric power systems and planning techniques. Credit will not be awarded for both ECE6322 and ECEP6305.

ECE.name: Power System Protection
ECE.description: Theory and practice of modern power system protection techniques. Credit will not be awarded for both ECE6323 and ECEP6351.

ECE.name: Power Electronic Devices and Subsystems
ECE.description: Physical considerations involved in the fabrication and use of power semiconductor devices and high-frequency magnetic transformers and inductors.

ECE.name: Power Electronic Circuits
ECE.description: The analysis control and design of switching power converters rectifiers cycloconverters voltage-sourced and current-source inverters dc-dc converters pfc and resonant converts.

ECE.name: Power Electronic CAD Laboratory
ECE.description: To introduce the use of CAD tools in the simulation analysis and design of power electronic circuits and systems.

ECE.name: Electric Machinery Analysis
ECE.description: An introduction to the analysis and basic construction principles of rotating electric machines and transformers including ac synchronous and induction machines and dc machines.  Credit is now allowed for both ECE4335 and ECE6335.

ECE.name: Dynamics and Control of Electric Machine Drives
ECE.description: A study of the dynamics and control of electric machinery and variable speed machine drive systems.

ECE.name: Electricity Markets
ECE.description: Comprehensive introduction to markets for electrical energy including economic theory market design utility models effects of the physical grid and grid services.

ECE.name: Applied Electromagnetics
ECE.description: The methodology and application of advanced electromagnetic theory.

ECE.name: Microwave Design
ECE.description: Applications of electromagnetic theory to microwave components and systems.  Introduction to the latest characterization and design techniques including monolithic microwave integrated circuit (MMIC) technology.

ECE.name: Microwave Design Laboratory
ECE.description: This laboratory course will teach microwave measurement/design fundamentals for both passive and active components.  Students will use both CAD tools and network analyzers.

ECE.name: Electromagnetic Radiation and Antennas
ECE.description: The fundamentals of electromagnetic radiation and antennas.

ECE.name: Introduction to Computational Electromagnetics
ECE.description: The practical application of the finite-difference time-domain and finite element techniques to electromagnetic problems. Computer projects are required.

ECE.name: Satellite Communications and Navigation Systems
ECE.description: To introduce satellite communications and navigation system design including microwave transmission satellite transponders earth station hardware and satellite networks. A design project is required.

ECE.name: Analog Integrated Circuit Design
ECE.description: Design of analog circuits using CMOS and bipolar technologies.

ECE.name: Analog Integrated System Design
ECE.description: Design of analog systems using CMOS and bipolar technologies. A higher level of design for analog and digital systems is presented.

ECE.name: Low Noise Electronic System Design
ECE.description: A study of the sources of noise found in electronic instrumentation. Teaches the recognition of sources of noise and the design techniques to achieve noise reduction.

ECE.name: Wireless IC Design
ECE.description: Wireless system specifications are translated to architectures and building blocks compatible with silicon technology.  The course focuses on the analysis and design of these blocks.

ECE.name: Interface IC Design for MEMS and Sensors
ECE.description: Design of high-performance integrated interface circuits for various MEMS and sensing devices.  System level issues in integrated microsystems.

ECE.name: Digital MOS Integrated Circuits
ECE.description: Detailed analysis of the operation and design of high- performance MOS digital integrated circuits.  Emphasis is on circuit design techniques with examples from the literature.

ECE.name: Neuromorphic Analog VLSI Circuits
ECE.description: Large-scale analog computation for sensory and motor processing.  Analog building blocks are presented leading to VLSI systems inspired by neurobiological architectures and computational paradigms.

ECE.name: Frequency Synthesizers
ECE.description: Frequency synthesizers generate many discrete RF frequencies from one reference frequency. General synthesizers digital PLL direct digital and hybrid synthesizers are covered.

ECE.name: Electronic Oscillators
ECE.description: Starting from nonlinear differential equations this course presents a systematic approach to the design of electronic oscillators. Design of negative resistance and feedback oscillators is discussed.  CAD techniques are employed.

ECE.name: Silicon-Based Heterostructure Devices and Circuits
ECE.description: Theory and design of novel silicon-germanium microelectronic devices and circuits.  Materials device physics fabrication measurement circuit design and system applications.

ECE.name: Power IC Design
ECE.description: Analysis and design of linear dc-dc regulators and switched-inductor dc-dc supplies with CMOS and BiCMOS integrated circuits (ICs).

ECE.name: Introduction to Microelectronics Technology
ECE.description: Presents the fundamentals of microelectronics material device and circuit fabrication.

ECE.name: Introduction to the Theory of Microelectronics
ECE.description: Basis of quantum mechanics statistical mechanics and the behavior of solids to serve as an introduction to the modern study of semiconductors and semiconductor devices.

ECE.name: Theory of Electronic Devices
ECE.description: Presents the fundamentals of electronic device operation.

ECE.name: Semiconductor Process Control
ECE.description: This course is designed to explore methods of applying statistical process control and statistical quality control to semiconductor manufacturing processes.  Students will be required to complete a design project.

ECE.name: Solar Cells
ECE.description: To provide a practical understanding of semiconductor materials and technology as it relates to design and development of efficient solar cells and photovoltaic systems.

ECE.name: Gigascale Integration
ECE.description: Hierarchy of physical principles that enable understanding and estimation of future opportunities to achieve multibillion transistor silicon chips using sub-0.25 micron technology.

ECE.name: Microelectromechanical Devices
ECE.description: Fundamental concepts for desgin of microelectromechanical devices (MEMS) including mechanical and thermal behavior of materials and structures transduction principles transducer design and modeling.

ECE.name: Carbon and Molecular Nanoelectronics
ECE.description: In this course carbon nanotubes are used as a framework to teach quantum transport as the foundatoin for all emerging nanoelectronic devices.

ECE.name: Fourier Techniques and Signal Analysis
ECE.description: Introduction to the use of Fourier Methods for analysis of signals.

ECE.name: Fourier Optics and Holography
ECE.description: Applications of the Fourier transform and linear systems theory to the analysis of optical propagation diffraction imaging holography wavefront modulation and signal processing.

ECE.name: Electro-Optics
ECE.description: Study of the fundamental principles and primary applications of lasers and of detectors of optical radiation.

ECE.name: Nanophotonics
ECE.description: Design of nano-structures to guide light and to develop a new set of optical devices.

ECE.name: Integrated Optics
ECE.description: Theory and design of optical waveguides and optical waveguide devices.

ECE.name: Optical Fibers
ECE.description: Provides an in-depth understanding of the light-guiding properties of optical fibers as used in communication systems.

ECE.name: Nonlinear Optics
ECE.description: Provides an introduction to the field of nonlinear optics exploring the physical mechanisms applications and experimental techniques.

ECE.name: Modulation, Diffractive, and Crystal Optics
ECE.description: Provides a working knowledge of temporal and spatial optical modulation diffractive optical devices and crystal optics.

ECE.name: Organic Optoelectronics
ECE.description: Fundamental understanding of the optical and electronic properties of organic materials and devices that form the basic of the emerging technological area of printed flexible optoelectronics.

ECE.name: Optoelectronics: Devices, Integration, Packaging, Systems
ECE.description: Optoelectronic devices (detectors emitters modulators) from the practical realized and theoretical performance perspective. Explores monolithic and hybrid integration of devices packaging and system implementation.

ECE.name: Fiber-optic Networks
ECE.description: Architectural performance and design aspects of fiber-optic communications networks components and technologies. Relationship between the physical network implementation and the higher-level network architecture.

ECE.name: Linear Systems and Controls
ECE.description: Introduction to linear system theory and feedback control. Topics include state space representations controllability and observability linear feedback control. Credit will not be awarded for both ECE6550 and AE6530.

ECE.name: Digital Control
ECE.description: Techniques for analysis and synthesis of computer-based control systems.  Design projects provide an understanding of the application of digital control to physical systems.

ECE.name: Nonlinear Systems and Control
ECE.description: Classical analysis techniques and stability theory for nonlinear systems.  Control design for nonlinear systems including robotic systems.  Design projects.

ECE.name: Optimal Control and Optimization
ECE.description: Optimal control of dynamic systems numerical optimization techniques and their applications in solving optical-trajectory problems.

ECE.name: Adaptive Control
ECE.description: Methods of parameter estimation and adaptive control for systems with constant or slowly varying unknown parameters. MATLAB design projects emphasizing applications to physical systems.

ECE.name: Optimal Estimation
ECE.description: Techniques for signal and state estimation in the presence of measurement and process noise with the emphasis on Wiener and Kalman filtering.

ECE.name: Intelligent Control
ECE.description: Principles of intelligent systems and their utility in modeling identification and control of complex systems neuro-fuzzy tools applied to supervisory control hands-on laboratory experience.

ECE.name: Manufacturing Systems Design
ECE.description: Analytic and simulation tools for design control and optimization of manufacturing systems. Discrete event dynamic systems and optimization.

ECE.name: Stochastic Systems
ECE.description: Advanced techniques in stochastic analysis with emphasis on stochastic dynamics nonlinear filtering and detection stochastic control and stochastic optimization and simulation methods.

ECE.name: Advanced Linear Systems
ECE.description: Study of multivariable linear system theory and robust control design methodologies.

ECE.name: Partial Differential Equations in Image Processing and Computer Vision
ECE.description: Mathematical foundations and numerical aspects of partial-differential equation techniques used in computer vision. Topics inculde image smoothing and enhancement edge detection morphology and image reconstruction.

ECE.name: Computing for Control Systems
ECE.description: Introduction to real-time computing distributed computing and software engineering in control systems.  The particular requirements of control systems will be presented.

ECE.name: Autonomous Control of Robotic Systems
ECE.description: Fundamental issues associated with autonomous robot control. Emphasizes biological perspective that forms the basis of many current developments in robotics.

ECE.name: Networked Control and Multiagent Systems
ECE.description: Covers tools and techniques for networked control systems as well as application domains and promising research directions.

ECE.name: Random Processes
ECE.description: To develop the theoretical framework for the processing of random signals and data.

ECE.name: Digital Communications
ECE.description: Basic M-ary digital communications systems with emphasis on system design and performance analysis in the presence of additive noise.

ECE.name: Advanced Digital Communications
ECE.description: The theory and practice of efficient digital communications over linear dispersive channels including adaptive equalization and synchronization.

ECE.name: Personal and Mobile Communications
ECE.description: To introduce various topics that are fundamental to cellular mobile telephone systems.

ECE.name: Information Theory
ECE.description: To introduce the mathematical theory of communications. Emphasis will be placed on Shannons theorems and their use in the analysis and design of communication systems.

ECE.name: Coding Theory and Applications
ECE.description: To introduce the theory and practice of error control coding with emphasis on linear cyclic convolutional and parallel concatenated codes.

ECE.name: Computer Communication Networks
ECE.description: Fundamental concepts of computer network architecture and protocols.

ECE.name: Performance Analysis of Communications Networks
ECE.description: Fundamental concepts of queuing systems and applications of queuing theory to the performance evaluation of computer networks.

ECE.name: Wireless Networks
ECE.description: Fundamental concepts of wireless networks.

ECE.name: Broadband Networking
ECE.description: Fundamental concepts of broadband networking including network models ATM networks quality of service and traffic management.

ECE.name: Computer Network Security
ECE.description: Fundamental concepts of network information security including encryption secure access methods and vulnerabilities in network protocols operating systems and network applications.

ECE.name: Broadband Access Networks
ECE.description: Study and comparison of ongoing and emerging access newtwork technologies including hybrid-fiber-coax FTTP/FTTH Gigabit Ethernet ADSL/VDSL and ultra wideband wireless data over fiber systems.

ECE.name: Multimedia Communications: Signal Processing, Networking, Applications, and Standards
ECE.description: Comprehensive coverage of media compression synthesis and recognition media communications and networking and standards for audiovisual communications over wired and wireless networks.

ECE.name: Sensor Networks
ECE.description: Basics of sensor network communications.  Applications architectures and communication protocols for sensor networks are treated in depth.

ECE.name: Cognitive Radio Networks
ECE.description: Scarce spectrum needs to be dynamically managed. Architectures and communication protocols such as spectrum sensing spectrum sharing and spectrum mobility are treated in depth.

ECE.name: Ethics of Biotechnology and Bioengineering Research
ECE.description: This course examines the ethics of biotechnological research including issues in the realm of research ethics bioethics and healthcare robotics.

ECE.name: Cyber Security Practicum
ECE.description: Capstone independent study project placing each student in a commercial academic or government setting where he or she identifies a major cyber security problem and explores and evaluates a solution that addresses it with realistic assumptions about the organizational context. The chosen problem must be approved by course instructor. Cross-listed with PUBP and CS6727.

ECE.name: Modeling and Simulation: Foundations and Implementation
ECE.description: Foundations and algorithms concerning the development of conceptual models for systems and their realization in the form of computer software discrete and continuous models. Crosslisted with CSE6730.

ECE.name: Topics in Engineering Practice
ECE.description: Topics of current importance offered in collaboration with an approved partner of Georgia Techs Distance Learning Program.  Crosslisted with ME6744.

ECE.name: Advanced Topics in Malware Analysis
ECE.description: This course covers advanced approaches for the analysis of malicious software and explores recent research and unsolved problems in software protection and forensics.

ECE.name: Plasma Processing of Electronic Materials and Devices
ECE.description: Fundamental physics chemistry chemical engineering and electrical engineering principles inherent in plasma processes.  Includes etching deposition diagnostic methods and control schemes. Crosslisted with CHE 6759.

ECE.name: Optoelectronics: Materials, Processes, Devices
ECE.description: Optoelectronic materials physical processes and devices. Includes compound semiconductor materials excitation recombination gain and modulation processes and devices such as emitters detectors and modulators. Crosslisted with PHYS6771.

ECE.name: Integrated Low-Cost Microelectronics Systems Packaging
ECE.description: Broad overview of system-level cross-disciplinary microelectronics packaging technologies including design test thermal reliability optoelectronics and RF integration.  Comparison of system-on-chip and system-on-package.  Crosslisted with ME and MSE6776.

ECE.name: Thermal Engineering for Packaging of Micro and Nano Systems
ECE.description: Passive active and hybrid thermal management techniques and computational modeling of micro systems. Air cooling simlge phase and phase change liquid cooling heat pipes and thermoelectrics. Crosslisted with ME6779.

ECE.name: Medical Image Processing
ECE.description: A study of methods for enhancing analyzing interpreting and visualizing information from two- and three-dimensional data obtained from a variety of medical imaging modalities. Crosslisted with CS and BMED6780.

ECE.name: Biomedical Sensing Systems
ECE.description: A study of physiological sensing topics from a systems viewpoint. Pertinent physiological and electro-physiological concepts will be covered. No prior knowledge of physiology or biology is needed.

ECE.name: Medical Imaging Systems
ECE.description: A study of the principles and design of medical imaging systems such as X-ray ultrasound nuclear medicine and nuclear magnetic resonance. Crosslisted with BMED6786.

ECE.name: Quantitative Electrophysiology
ECE.description: A quantitative presentation of electrophysiological systems in biological organisms emphasizing the electrical properties and modeling of neural and cardiac cells and systems. Crosslisted with BMED and PHYS6787.

ECE.name: Information Processing Models in Neural Systems
ECE.description: Examines top-down modeling approaches for sensorineural systems where optimal computational principles used in engineering(e.g. information theory Bayesian inference control theory) explain observed information processing.

ECE.name: Manufacturing Seminar
ECE.description: Guest speakers on a broad range of manufacturing-related topics research applications and technology. Required for Certificate in Manufacturing. Crosslisted with ISYE and ME6792.

ECE.name: GT-SJTU
ECE.description: For GT-SJTU dual-MS students during terms when they are not taking other GT courses.  Placeholder course.

ECE.name: GT-TU
ECE.description: For GT-TU double-MS students during terms when they are not taking other GT courses.

ECE.name: GT-Shenzhen Research
ECE.description: For GT-Shenzhen students during terms when they are in Atlanta on research internship with GT-Atlanta faculty.

ECE.name: RISC Architectures
ECE.description: An advanced design-oriented class studying the design techniques and operational principles of modern Superscalar RISC datapaths.

ECE.name: Advanced Memory System
ECE.description: Covers the basic trade-offs in architecting a high performance memory hierarchy at all levels starting from the on-chip cache to main memory and storage sub-system.

ECE.name: Asynchronous and Self-timed Systems
ECE.description: Specification and design of asynchronous digital systems.

ECE.name: Advanced Digital Systems Test
ECE.description: Design and test techniques for high-speed digital systems operating at rates above 100 MHz with a practical emphasis via substantial projects.

ECE.name: Fault Tolerant Computing
ECE.description: Key concepts in fault-tolerant computing.  Understanding and use of modern fault-tolerant hardware and software design practices. Case studies.

ECE.name: Signal Detection and Estimation
ECE.description: Detection theory and estimation theory and their application to communications and statistical signal processing problems.

ECE.name: Advanced Signal Processing Theory
ECE.description: A lecture and seminar treatment of the latest developments in signal processing.  Emphasis is placed on current literature and emerging research areas.

ECE.name: Topics in Analytical Electromagnetics
ECE.description: An in-depth treatment of several analytical techniques used in current practice for solving real-world EM wave propagation problems and their impact on wireless communications.

ECE.name: Antennas and Wave Propagation in Matter
ECE.description: Basic methods for characterizing the electromagnetic properties of common materials (geophysical biological etc.) and techniques for analyzing antennas and wave propagation in these materials.

ECE.name: Topics in Computational Electromagnetics
ECE.description: Computational approaches for applications such as radar signature prediction microwave antenna and device design and modeling techniques for electronic packaging.

ECE.name: Advanced Communication Theory
ECE.description: Latest developments in communications and networking are treated in lecture and seminar.  Emphasis on current literature and open research areas.

ECE.name: Robotics Professional Preparation
ECE.description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local  visiting speakers. Program introduction. Technical resume preparation. GT Robotics labs  resources.

ECE.name: Robotics Professional Preparation 2
ECE.description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local  visiting speakers. Selecting and applying for Internship. Developing capstone project proposal. Public speaking practice and preparation.

ECE.name: Robotics Professional Preparation 3
ECE.description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local  visiting speakers. Interview preparation  career search. Technical report writing and presentation.

ECE.name: Mathematical Foundations of Machine Learning
ECE.description: Provides the mathematical background for two of the pillars of modern data science linear algebra and applied probability.

ECE.name: Probabilistic Graphical Models in Machine Learning
ECE.description: The course provides an introduction to theory and practice of graphical models in machine learning. It covers three main aspects representation probabilistic inference and learning.

ECE.name: Introduction to Robotics Research
ECE.description: Familiarizes students with the core areas of robotics mechanics control perception AI and autonomy. Provides an introduction to the mathematical tools required in robotics research.

ECE.name: Preparation for Doctoral Qualifying Examination
ECE.description: This course is reseved for students who are studying for the ECE Preliminary Exam.

ECE.name: ECE Seminar
ECE.description: Speakers with diverse backgrounds and representing many different industries professions and institutions describe their experiences entrepreneurial ventures and research challenges.

ECE.name: ECE Seminar
ECE.description: Speakers with diverse backgrounds and representing different industries professions and institutions describe their experiences entrepreneurial ventures and research challenges.

ECE.name: ECE Seminar

ECE.name: Special Topics
ECE.description: Empirical security research seeks to understand how computer security concerns manifest in practice. For example what strategies and techniques do attackers actually use and how do they profit from their actions? How do users behave in different security contexts and why do they behave in those (often insecure) ways? Gaining this understanding is vital for driving improvements in real-world security. This seminar-style course will cover both classic and recent empirical security studies across a wide range of security topics including Internet security underground ecosystems usable security and online privacy. You will analyze critique and discuss these works. Beyond broadening your knowledge of real-world computer security you will gain a deeper understanding of sound and rigorous measurement methodologies for applying to your own work.

GRMN.description: The European Union plays an increasing role in European politics and daily life. This seminar examines the origins of the European Union its institutions legal framework and current topics such as immigration enlargement and relationships with other countries. Taught in German.

GRMN.name: Literary Representations of German History
GRMN.description: This course examines how literary representation reveals interpretations of historical events and the relationship between history and fiction in selected German history. Taught in German.

GRMN.name: Advanced Stylistics: Grammar and Discourse
GRMN.description: This course incorporates study of stylistic difference and idiomatic usages of German expands vocabulary and solidifies and enlarges upon grammatical and syntactic structures.  Taught in German.

GRMN.name: S&T in German History and Culture
GRMN.description: Course surveys the history of science technology and industrialization in German-speaking countries as well as current STEM research in German. Taught in German.

GRMN.name: Advanced Intercultural Seminar
GRMN.description: Integrates cross-cultural research and reflection into discussion of current issues Germany.  Intended for students who have had some study-abroad experience in Germany.  Conducted in German.

GRMN.name: Berlin: The Capital in the 20th Century
GRMN.description: By engaging contemporaneous topics in film literature photography etc. students will investigate topics that dominated the different periods of Berlins turbulent history.  Taught in German.

GRMN.name: Industrial Transformation and German Society/Economy
GRMN.description: Examination of technological and societal changes resulting from transformation of an industrial area to one dominated by high tech and media industries.  Taught in German.

GRMN.name: German Internship
GRMN.description: Professional experience with a business/organization in which students enhance their language skills and cultural knowledge in German in relation to the practical goals/objectives of the entity.

GRMN.name: Internship Assistantship
GRMN.description: Modern Language Undergraduate Internship for pay for junior and seniors by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Modern Languages.

GRMN.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

GRMN.name: Advanced German Grammar
GRMN.description: Study and practice of advanced grammatical structures for complex communicative settings. Taught in German.

GRMN.name: Perspectives of German Media
GRMN.description: Studies of various German media sources applied towards the development of a critical understanding of media languages to influence persuade inform and entertain. Taught in German.

GRMN.name: German Political Songwriting
GRMN.description: This class offers an overview of political songwriting in Germany (GDR and FRG) between 1945 and the present.

GRMN.name: Americanization and Anti-Americanism in the Federal Republic of Germany
GRMN.description: This class surveys the reception of US culture in West Germany from the end of WWII to today. Taught in German.

GRMN.name: German Domestic Internship
GRMN.description: Students complete domestic internships.  Conducted in German.  Online course.

GRMN.name: S&T in German History and Culture
GRMN.description: Course surveys the history of science technology and industrialization in German-speaking countries as well as current STEM research in German. Taught in German.

GRMN.description: Integrates cross-cultural research and reflection into discussion of current issues in Germany. Taught in German.

GRMN.name: Professional Portfolio Development
GRMN.description: Preparation of a professional portfolio connecting experiences and coursework in the MS program towards career preparation. Conducted in German.

GRMN.name: Applied Language Practicum
GRMN.description: Students will serve as researchers student aides and apprentice instructors for any 3/4000-level undergraduate course approved by their adviser and the course.

GRMN.name: Applied Language Practicum Abroad
GRMN.description: Students serve as researchers and apprentice instructors in the LBAT or other faculty-led overseas language immersion program of the School of Modern Languages.

GRMN.description: German Internship Abroad.

GRMN.name: German Internship Abroad
GRMN.description: Students complete internships abroad in a German-speaking country. Conducted in German. Online course.

HP.name: Radiological Health I
HP.description: Applied nuclear and atomic physics radioactive decay radiation interactions radiation dosimetry and safety guidelines instrumentation radiation protection and basics of criticality safety.

HP.name: Radiological Health II
HP.description: Radiation quantities microdosimetry biological effects of ionizing radiation radiation risk internal radiation protection ALARA and radiological emergency response.

HP.name: Applied Radiological Health Laboratory
HP.description: Advanced laboratory course in radiochemical and instrumental analysis. Practical radiation/radioactivity monitoring problems in nuclear facilities and environmental surveillance.

HP.name: Operational Health Physics
HP.description: Radiation sources radiological safety practices and procedures for nuclear facilities and the impact of radiological safety in the design of such facilities.

HP.name: Industrial Hygiene
HP.description: Chemical physical biological and ergonomic exposures. Occupational environment regulations.  Application of scientific and engineering principles to hazard evaluation and general occupational health control measures.

HP.name: Radiological Assessment and Waste Management
HP.description: Critical analyses of sources and human exposures mathematical models for movement through the biosphere environmental transport and exposure for nuclear facilities and waste disposal processing. Crosslisted with NRE6755.

HP.name: Radiation Physics
HP.description: Characteristics of atomic and nuclear radiation transition probabilities radioactivity and isotopes cross sections electromagnetic radiation neutrons and charged particle interaction with matter. Crosslisted with NRE6756.

HP.name: Radiation Detection
HP.description: Introduction to the theory and application of radiation detectors measurement methods signal processing and data analysis. Crosslisted with NRE6757.

HP.name: Numerical Methods in Mechanical Engineering
HP.description: Numerical methods for solution of engineering problems initial eigenvalue and boundary-value problems computational stability for ordinary and linear partial differential equations.  Crosslisted with ME and NRE6758.

HP.name: Teaching Practicum
HP.description: Supervised teaching for doctoral students.  Teaching techniques course and curriculum design student evaluation methods and criteria.  Students may in some instances prepare and present lectures.  Crosslisted with NRE ME and CHBE7757.

HP.name: Seminars in Health Physics
HP.description: Seminars involving current research projects presented by graduate students faculty and invited speakers.

HP.name: Seminars in Health Physics
HP.description: Seminars involving current research projects presented by graduate students faculty and invited speakers.

HS.name: Introduction to Health Systems
HS.description: Background of U.S. healthcare the workforce mechanisms and costs of delivery facilities ambulatory care regulation and quality managed care finance and role of government.

HS.name: Introduction to Healthcare Delivery
HS.description: Historical background the healthcare workforce nature problems and costs of delivery sites health planning finance role of government alternative delivery models and health policy.

HS.name: Healthcare Delivery Systems Models
HS.description: Progression in service delivery from individual providers to complex financing and delivery organizations. Alternative models are explored with an emphasis on access efficiency and effectiveness.

HS.name: Healthcare Financial Management
HS.description: Applications of accounting and finance in the healthcare delivery system methods of reimbursement product costing strategic financial planning and capital formation.

HS.name: Healthcare Information Systems
HS.description: Application of information systems to assist in medical practice including communication within the healthcare enterprise reimbursement for care clinical decision making and assessment of outcomes.

HS.name: Health Systems Practice
HS.description: An actual project conducted by individual graduate students within a healthcare institution or a health service organization.  Project has both a faculty and site sponsor.

HEBW.description: Students acquire reading and writing skills and the ability to communicate in basic situations. Taught in Hebrew.

HEBW.name: Elementary Hebrew II
HEBW.description: Students acquire reading and writing skills and the ability to communicate in basic situations. Continuation of HEBW1001. Taught in Hebrew.

HEBW.name: Intrmediate Hebrew I
HEBW.description: Development of grammatical concepts vocabulary and conversational abilities. Readings audio and video material on the culture. Taught in Hebrew.

HEBW.name: Intrmediate Hebrew II
HEBW.description: Continued development of grammatical concepts vocabulary and conversational abilities. Readings audio and video material on the culture. Taught in Hebew.

HIN.name: Elementary Hindi I
HIN.description: This first introductory Hindi course teaches basic grammar and develops listening speaking reading and writing skills. Taught in Hindi. No native speakers allowed.

HIN.name: Elementary Hindi II
HIN.description: A continuation to HIND 1001 this course teaches basic grammar and develops listening speaking reading and writing skills. Taught in Hindi. No native speakers allowed.

HIST.name: The United States to 1877
HIST.description: Colonial settlement the American Revolution and the Constitution antebellum expansion slavery and plantation economy sectional conflict and Civil War Reconstruction.

HIST.name: The United States since 1877
HIST.description: The social political and economic history of the United States since Reconstruction.  Topics include American industrialization two world wars New Deal and the Civil Rights movement.

HTS.name: Introduction to History, Technology, and Society
HTS.description: An introduction to classic texts key concepts and research opportunitites in history and sociology.

HTS.name: Europe Since the Renaissance
HTS.description: Social political economic and cultural history of Europe since the Renaissance.  Topics include Renaissance Reformation political scientific and industrial revolutions nationalism fascism and communism decolonization.

HTS.name: Engineering in History
HTS.description: Uses historical case studies to examine the relationship between engineers and the larger society in which they function.  Often taught jointly with engineering faculty.

HTS.name: Early American History
HTS.description: North America to 1763 including native cultures contacts with European colonizers settlement strategies and patterns and foundation of American political and economic institutions.

HTS.name: The American Revolution and Constitution
HTS.description: The American Revolution as political debate war and social upheaval with attention to the framing and ratification of the Constitution.

HTS.name: History of the Old South to 1865
HTS.description: A study of social political and economic developments in the South from the colonial period through the Civil War.

HTS.name: History of the New South since 1865
HTS.description: An examination of social political and economic developments from the Reconstruction period to the present.

HTS.name: The Gilded Age and the Progressive Era
HTS.description: Populism the currency question immigration the rise of big business war and reform in one of the most turbulent periods of American history.

HTS.name: Modern America: World War II and After
HTS.description: Dawning of the atomic age anticommunism the Civil Rights Movement New Frontier and Great Society Vietnam and the tumultuous 1960s and end of Cold War.

HTS.name: History of Sports in America
HTS.description: Examines American sport from colonial to contemporary times. Focuses on the rise of organized sports and the influence of race class gender and ethnicity.

HTS.name: Social Issues and Public Policy
HTS.description: Draws on sociological theory and research to understand the major economic social and cultural issues facing American society today.

HTS.name: Revolutionary Europe: 1789-1914
HTS.description: Industrialization and political revolution the development of political ideologies and labor activism modern nation-state building and imperialism from the French Revolution to World War I.

HTS.name: Twentieth Century Europe: 1914 to Present
HTS.description: Global war and the Bolshevik Revolution rise and fall of Mussolini and Hitler Stalinism the Holocaust Cold War decolonization and the movement toward European integration.

HTS.name: History of Islamic Societies
HTS.description: Survey of Middle East from pre-Islamic times to Ottoman rule tracing the development of Islamic society and emphasizing the plurality of culture in the region.

HTS.name: History of the Modern Middle East
HTS.description: The transformation of the Middle East in the modern era and the relationship of the East and West in the contemporary world.

HTS.name: Colonial Latin America and the World
HTS.description: An exploration of colonial Latin America from the perspective of Global History.

HTS.name: North American Borderlands
HTS.description: Introduction to the history of early Florida Georgia Louisiana Texas New Mexico Arizona and California in the Spanish Colonial period.

HTS.name: Traditional Asia and Its Legacy
HTS.description: Civilizations of East Asia up to 1850 emphasizing traditional cultures in China and Japan including religion science formation of empires social life and commerce.

HTS.name: Asia in the Modern World
HTS.description: Civilizations of India China and Japan since 1600 emphasizing Western impact and adaptation of these countries political economic and social systems.

HTS.name: Introduction to the History of Disease and Medicine
HTS.description: Introduction to the history of disease and medicine since the Renaissance focusing on infectious diseases the rise of germ theory and evolution of medical training.  Cerdit not allowed for both HTS2080 and HTS3087.

HTS.name: The Scientific Revolution
HTS.description: A critical approach to the Scientific Revolution introducing students to primary documents and images from the period and emphasizing interpretive strategies and methods.

HTS.name: Technology and Science in the Industrial Age
HTS.description: Surveys major developments in technology and science since 1600 and places them in the broader social context of their times.

HTS.name: Technology and Society
HTS.description: Analyzes social conditions that promote or retard technological activity emphasizing role of business the state and scientific and engineering professions and the emergence of consumerism.

HTS.name: Reel History I: US History through Hollywood Films
HTS.description: Students evaluate films as sources for specific historical events by viewing films reading historical documents and applying critical analysis to written assignments and class discussions.

HTS.name: Semester in the City: Engaging Communities
HTS.description: Explores how urban neighborhoods work focusing on Westside neighborhoods from a variety of perspectives. Students will work with residents in designing a sustainability project.

HTS.name: Sci, Tech & Modern World
HTS.description: An introduction to perspectives on how developments in science and technology at once reflect and influence politics and society on a global scale.

HTS.name: Historical and Social Research
HTS.description: Interdisciplinary survey based on critical readings of the methods historians and social scientists use to generate knowledge about social life.  Students engage in hands-on research.

HTS.name: HTS Internship - Paid
HTS.description: Undergraduate internship for which the student is paid and receives audit credit. Freshmen and sophomores only.

HTS.name: HTS Internship-Credit
HTS.description: Unpaid undergraduate internship for which the student receives pass/fail credit. Freshmen and sophomores only.

HTS.name: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
HTS.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

HTS.name: Undergraduate Research
HTS.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

HTS.name: Special Topics
HTS.description: Allows a group of students and a professor to study topics not covered in other courses in the department.

HTS.name: Special Topics
HTS.description: Allows a group of students and a professor to study topics not covered in other courses in the department.

HTS.name: Special Topics
HTS.description: Allows a group of students and a professor to study topics not covered in other courses in the department.

HTS.name: American Economic History
HTS.description: U.S. economic history since 1607 including regional specialization agriculture industrialization technology government and economy money and banking labor international trade and contemporary economic problems.

HTS.name: History of American Business
HTS.description: Evolution of business institutions from colonial period to present including entrepreneurship business-government relations institutional innovation and twentieth century managerial capitalism.

HTS.name: Sociology of Economic Institutions
HTS.description: Examines links between economic structures-markets regulatory bodies and labor relations systems-and the wider structural and cultural context.

HTS.name: American Environmental History
HTS.description: Transformation of the North American environment since 1500 including different notions of nature romantic responses to wilderness during industrialization rise of conservation movements and environmental policy.

HTS.name: United States Labor History
HTS.description: The changing nature of work and labor relations with focus on unionization and government regulation and equity issues in the workplace.

HTS.name: Sociology of Work, Industry, and Occupations
HTS.description: Analyzes paid employment as a decisive social attachment emphasizing work organizations technological change and authority relations and social inequality among diverse groups of employees.

HTS.name: Class, Power, and Social Inequality
HTS.description: This course examines how social class and the market economy affect inequality and stratification in the U.S. with additional attention to the roles of race and gender.

HTS.name: The American Civil War
HTS.description: Social economic political and military aspects of the Civil War including causes of the war military campaigns and long-term consequences.

HTS.name: The City in American History
HTS.description: Examines the historical background of the American city since colonial times including city planning urban technology and services neighborhoods and race relations.

HTS.name: Urban Sociology
HTS.description: Sociological perspectives on the city urbanization and problems of community evolution of cities and problems of urban life in the United States and Third World.

HTS.name: History of the Vietnam War
HTS.description: Diplomatic military and social aspects of Americas war in Vietnam including antiwar protests the defense industry boom and the wars enduring impact on American life.

HTS.name: Women and Gender in the United States
HTS.description: Course examines themes and theories of womens and gender history since the colonial period including work family race sexuality and politics.

HTS.name: Sociology of Gender
HTS.description: Gender as a dimension of social life that shapes and is shaped by the economy schooling family politics medicine and health race and social class.

HTS.name: New Religions and Cults in America
HTS.description: Explores controversial and influential new religious movements and cults in America focusing on their origin appeal and impact.

HTS.name: The Family, Sexuality, and Social Change in America
HTS.description: Changing patterns of family life and sex roles since colonial times with a focus on mainstream ideals utopian alternatives and social criticism.

HTS.name: Gender and Technology
HTS.description: Course examines the ways in which the design development and application of technologies as well as cultural responses to them have been gendered historically.

HTS.name: Women in Science and Engineering
HTS.description: Women in science and engineering and gender differences in participation location and status.  Examines education access and apprenticeship culture of science and engineering.

HTS.name: Gender and Sports
HTS.description: Examines how gender norms and beliefs shape sport structures participation opportunities and experiences in American sport.

HTS.name: Slaves without Masters: Free People of Color before 1865
HTS.description: Free people of color during the era of slavery including everyday life political and social philosophies literature community development and movements for social change.

HTS.name: African American History to 1865
HTS.description: The experience of African and African American people in North America from the beginnings of slavery until the era of emancipation in the Civil War.

HTS.name: African American History since 1865
HTS.description: The African American experience since 1865 including Reconstruction segregation the African American family the Harlem Renaissance the Civil Rights Movement and Black Power.

HTS.name: Sociology of Race and Ethnicity
HTS.description: Nature and significance of dominant/minority relations including legacies of colonialism and slavery roots of residential segregation and effects of race on American politics.

HTS.name: The Civil Rights Movement
HTS.description: Examines why the civil rights movement emerged how it was successful and the impact it had on the U.S.

HTS.name: Ancient Greece: Gods, Heroes, and RuinS
HTS.description: Classical Athens and Sparta myths and legends in historical context. Course ends with Alexander the Great and the rise of Rome.

HTS.name: Ancient Rome: From Greatness to Ruins
HTS.description: Growth of the Republic antics and follies of the emperors accomplishments of Rome and causes of decline. Early Christianity and its impact on Europe included.

HTS.name: Medieval Europe: 350 to 1400
HTS.description: The rise of barbarian kingdoms from Romes ashes the explosion of  Islam the monastic movement Charlemagnes empire the blossoming of medieval culture and developinG European monarchies.

HTS.name: European Labor History
HTS.description: The labor movement from 1700s to the present including an examination of Marx and socialism unionization and work conditions especially in Britain Germany and France.

HTS.name: Modern European Intellectual History
HTS.description: Introduction to intellectual problems and trends in modern Europe including loss of faith in progress evil and ethics post-colonialism feminism linguistics and psycho-analytic thought.

HTS.name: Medieval England
HTS.description: Political economic and cultural development of England during the Middle Ages (c. 350-1400). Myths and legends of Stonehenge the Druids and King Arthurs Camelot explored.

HTS.name: Britain from 1815-1914
HTS.description: Developments in nineteenth-century Britain including the industrial revolution the growth of political democracy imperialism and movements for Irish Home rule and democratic socialism.

HTS.name: Britain Since 1914
HTS.description: Britains experience of two world wars the growth of Labour and decline of the Liberals the Welfare State Thatcherism and Tony Blairs New Labour.

HTS.name: The French Revolution
HTS.description: Economic intellectual and cultural causes of the French Revolution Jacobinism and the Terror careers of Robespierre and Danton and rise and fall of Napoleons empire.

HTS.name: Modern France
HTS.description: France from 1815 to 1968 emphasizing the continuing project of creating France as a powerful nation within the context of global culture and politics.

HTS.name: Modern Spain
HTS.description: Resistance to Napoleon deformed industrialization Anarchist and fascist experiments form the background for Spains transition from dictatorship to democracy after Francos death.

HTS.name: Modern Germany
HTS.description: Consolidation of Germany since Napoleonic wars Germanys contributions both hideous and glorious to Europe and the West and recent unification of East and West Germany.

HTS.name: Nazi Germany and the Holocaust
HTS.description: Genocide in the twentieth century emphasizing the extermination of European Jews. Course investigates roots of racism eugenics and ideologies of genocide in comparative perspective.

HTS.name: Science, Poliltics, and Culture in Nazi Germany
HTS.description: Examines the social political and cultural context of science and technology in Nazi Germany to understand the interaction of science and politics under totalitarian regimes.

HTS.name: Modern Russian History
HTS.description: Provides an overview of Russian history during the 20th Century.  Special emphasis will be on the Soviet period of Russian history from 1917-1991.

HTS.name: Women and the Politics of Gender in the Middle East
HTS.description: The role of women in imperial nationalist and Islamist political programs in the Middle East and the impact of politics on womens lives.

HTS.name: Globalization in the Modern Era
HTS.description: This course examines the process of globalization and global change in the twentieth century.  Also offers a critical examination of various theories of globalization.

HTS.name: Modern China
HTS.description: The decline of Confucian order the impact of the West changes and continuities of Chinese culture the Communist revolution nationalism and economic reforms since 1978.

HTS.name: Modern Japan
HTS.description: Japans transformation in one century from a feudal state into an economic superpower and the impact of these changes on the Japanese people.

HTS.name: Outposts of Empire: Comparative History of British
HTS.description: Analysis of four British settlement colonies-Australia New Zealand Canada and South Africa-emphasizing settlement race relations and national identity.

HTS.name: Sociology of Development
HTS.description: Course examines competing perspectives on international development and surveys some of the crucial issues including political instability facing the Third World today.

HTS.name: History of Global Societies
HTS.description: Examines the historical patterns of interaction and inter- dependence between world regions from approximately the 13th century to global interdependence to the contemporary world.

HTS.name: Sociology of Politics and Society
HTS.description: Political sociology studies the way power is distributed in society. This course takes a comparative and historical approach focusing on the development of the nation-state.

HTS.name: Revolutionary Movements in the Modern World
HTS.description: Comparative analysis of the origin development and impact of major twentieth century revolutionary movements.

HTS.name: Social Movements
HTS.description: Why do social movements emerge? Why might they succeed? This course examines how ordinary people challenge powerful segments of society and contribute to social change.

HTS.name: Modern Cuba
HTS.description: Cuba since 1492 emphasizing slavery and sugar wars of independence the revolution of 1959 and the regime of Fidel Castro.

HTS.name: Culture and Society
HTS.description: Covers core issues in the study of culture. Focuses on key sites social practices and institutions. Topics include education medicine consumption and the mass media.

HTS.name: Sociology of Crime
HTS.description: This course examines the theories and issues such as perceptions of crime and criminals characteristics of offenders and victims and how crime is studied.

HTS.name: Sociology of Education
HTS.description: Examines sociological perspectives on how individual school and social factors influence students and teachers. Particular attention is paid to gender race ethnicity and social class.

HTS.name: Sociology of Sports
HTS.description: Examines what constitutes sports and uses sociological lens to study sports relationship to education policy media deviance violence as well as gender race and class.

HTS.name: Foundations of Sports Studies
HTS.description: Offers case studies of the multidisciplinary study of sports using the lenses of history sociology economics science and technology to understand sports practices and controversies.

HTS.name: History of Intelligence and National Security
HTS.description: Examines the Cold Wars most important spy cases and operations to better understand the interplay between the world of secrets and intelligence and the world of statecraft and technology.

HTS.name: History of Rocketry
HTS.description: Examines the history of rocketry scientists and organizations in the US USSR and Europe during the twentieth century.

HTS.name: Technology and the Environment
HTS.description: Examines how technology affected the environment during the 20th Century with special attention to issues like industrialization pollution overcrowding and the biotech revolution.

HTS.name: Sociology of Science
HTS.description: The growth of science its social structure deviance and norms the social context of scientific knowledge and practice and science policy.  Credit not allowed for both HTS3082 and HTS6115.

HTS.name: Technology and the Shaping of American Society
HTS.description: The complex interplay between technical innovation and cultural change in the United States since 1850 with emphasis on the emergence of modern consumer-oriented society.

HTS.name: Culture and Technology
HTS.description: Modernism and post-modernism this course investigates culturally creative responses to modern manufacturing transportation (trains cars airplanes) evolving gender ideals and new communications.

HTS.name: Law, Technology, and Politics
HTS.description: Examines the ways in which courts legislatures and regulatory agencies have responded to challenges posed by new technology and shaped the course of technical change.

HTS.name: Sociology of Medicine and Health
HTS.description: Relationship between health and society including health care problems in the United States and cultures role in defining health and sickness and in determining appropriate therapies.

HTS.name: History of Medicine
HTS.description: An introduction to historical perspectives on the development of medicine and its relationship to health illness and society.  Credit not allowed for both HTS3087 and HTS2080.

HTS.name: Race, Medicine & Science
HTS.description: Examines how race is an issue in medicine and science in ways such as education professions treatments experiments and as a subject of analysis.

HTS.name: Sceince, Technology and Sports
HTS.description: This course examines what constitutes a sport debates on the role of social inequality in sports and the intersection of science technology and sport.

HTS.name: Introduction to Museum Studies
HTS.description: Covers theoretical and practical issues in museum studies including the role of material culture in scholarly work registration of artifacts exhibit design and public relations.

HTS.name: Social Theory and Social Structure
HTS.description: Introduction to social theory providing students with skills for reading theory and examining works of major social theorists including Marx Weber Durkheim Gilman and Bourdieu.

HTS.name: Honor's Thesis
HTS.description: This course is designed to allow honors students to distinguish themselves by producing a significant original research paper.
