LMC.name: Introduction to Literature, Media, and Communication
LMC.description: An the introductory course to LMC this course introduces students to key texts and modes of analysis associated with the study of literature film digital media and communication.

LMC.name: Seminar in Literature, Media, and Communication
LMC.description: This course introduces second-semester majors to the intellectual movements interpretive frameworks and research skills central to the disciplines represented in LMC.

LMC.name: Introduction to Literary Studies
LMC.description: Students will study literary and cultural texts methods and critical movements from a variety of perspectives and historical periods.

LMC.name: Introduction to Science, Technology and Culture
LMC.description: Relation to other courses programs and curricula As the introductory course to the LMC Science Technology and Culture thread this course explores the way in which disciplines construct and represent the knowledge they generate.

LMC.name: Introduction to Gender Studies
LMC.description: This course introduces the cultural concept of gender examining topics such as biology and gender social constructions of gender and the psychology of sexual roles.

LMC.name: Introduction to Social Justice
LMC.description: Introduces students to the work and theory of social justice through readings from various disciplines including literature history anthropology philosophy science policy and law.

LMC.name: Introduction to Media Studies
LMC.description: This course offers an introduction to the historical development and cultural impact of various forms of media print radio television film and interactive electronic applications.

LMC.name: Introduction to Game Studies
LMC.description: Introduction to the games studies and game designs.

LMC.name: Introduction to Film
LMC.description: Introduces film techniques and vocabulary in an historical and cultural context. Written texts are supplemented by viewings of specific shots scenes and films.

LMC.name: LMC 2500 Recitation
LMC.description: Film Screening for Introduction to Film.

LMC.name: Introduction to Performance Studies
LMC.description: An examination of the origins of the field of performance studies in literary study of theatre and drama anthropological investigations of ritual and sociological analyses of performance in everyday life.

LMC.name: Theatre Production I
LMC.description: In this hands-on course students learn theatrical construction and painting techniques while building scenery for DramaTech productions.

LMC.name: Theatre Production II
LMC.description: In this hands-on course students create the lighting property and costume effects for two DramaTech Theatre productions.

LMC.name: Research Assistantship
LMC.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

LMC.name: Undergraduate Research
LMC.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

LMC.name: Introduction to Computational Media
LMC.description: Introduction to key concepts methods and achievements in computational media and the convergence of digital technology with cultural traditions of representation.

LMC.name: Principles of Visual Design
LMC.description: Studio-based course that provides students with basic skills needed to create digital visual images and to analyze designs from historical and theoretical perspectives.

LMC.name: Constructing the Moving Image
LMC.description: Provides the student with the conceptual formal aesthetic and technical approaches to reconsider film videos and animation within the context of emerging digital forms.

LMC.name: Special Topics in Literature and Culture
LMC.description: Examination of one or more topics of current interest in literary and cultural studies.

LMC.name: Science, Technology, and the Classical Tradition
LMC.description: Explores the definition and transmission of science and technology within Greek Arabic and medieval Latin contexts.

LMC.name: The Age of Scientific Discovery
LMC.description: Examines the relationships among texts representing the literary artistic and scientific thought of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries.

LMC.name: The Age of Scientific Revolution
LMC.description: Examines interrelation of technological literary artistic and philosophical thought in the late sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.

LMC.name: Evolution and the Industrial Age
LMC.description: Connects later nineteenth century scientific and technological concepts and discoveries particularly theories of evolution to the literature and culture of the industrial age.

LMC.name: Studies in Fiction
LMC.description: Examines the elements of fiction and what has made fiction especially the novel distinctive popular and enduring. Readings may include formal cultural and historical theories.

LMC.name: Poetry and Poetics
LMC.description: A study of traditions of poetic practice and poetic theory in English through intensive line by line readings of poems from different periods in literary history.

LMC.name: Communication and Culture
LMC.description: Examines ways in which forms and media of communication create and are created by other cultural constructs.

LMC.name: African American Literature and Culture
LMC.description: Explores the works of African American writers from the Colonial period to the present and examines a variety of cultural constructs that have fundamentally shaped the African American literary tradition.

LMC.name: Ethnicity in American Culture
LMC.description: Explores literary and historical works considering ethnic issues in American culture including immigration social assimilation double consciousness the development of ethnic identity/pride and multiculturalism.

LMC.name: Women, Literature, and Culture
LMC.description: Students in this course will analyze writings by women and examine feminist and other relevant cultural critiques of literature.

LMC.name: Science Fiction
LMC.description: Examines science fiction texts from the last 200 years to show how they reflect ambigous reactions to change.

LMC.name: Science Fiction Film and Television
LMC.description: This course investigates science fiction as the genre developed during film history and has become one of the most popular forms of television narrative.

LMC.name: LMC 3215 Recitation
LMC.description: Film Screening for Science Fiction Film  Television.

LMC.name: Literature and Medicine
LMC.description: This course examines works of literature dealing overtly with illness and healing works about or by physicians and other caregivers and works that raise questions about ethical behavior in the face of sickness.

LMC.name: Gender Studies in the Disciplines
LMC.description: This course explores the concept of gender and its usefulness as a theoretical category in a variety of disciplines. It includes cultural studies of literature communication media cultural anthropology sociology history and science.

LMC.name: Major Authors
LMC.description: An examination of the works and career of a major author in historical and cultural context.

LMC.name: Shakespeare
LMC.description: An examination of Shakespeares works with attention to generic conventions historical context and the relationship of text and performance. Major works of Shakespeares contemporaries are studied as appropriate.

LMC.name: Creative Writing
LMC.description: This course explores a range of creative literary genres and combines study and analysis of existing modes of one or more forms in order to establish a basis for original creative work by class members.

LMC.name: Writing for the Stage and Screen
LMC.description: Basic principles of generating creative concepts dramatic structure character and dialogue development and formatting for stage and screenplays.

LMC.name: Studies in Film and Television
LMC.description: Explores in depth a theoretical issue central to film and/or television. Among its concerns are authorship genre history spectatorship ideology narrative theory and the relationship between these media and social history.

LMC.name: LMC 3252 Recitation
LMC.description: Film Screening for Studies in Film  Television.

LMC.name: Animation
LMC.description: This course examines animation from its earliest days as a cinema of attractions to its current development as a predominantly digital practice.

LMC.name: LMC 3253 Recitation
LMC.description: Film Screening for Animation.

LMC.name: Film History
LMC.description: Surveys the history of film from its machine origins to its present digital developments. It focuses on various movements figures and narrative developments in world cinema.

LMC.name: LMC 3254 Recitation
LMC.description: Film Screening for Film History.

LMC.name: Cinema and Digital Culture
LMC.description: This course examines the impact of digital technologies on contemporary cinema as well as the influence of different cinematic traditions on new digital media.

LMC.name: LMC 3255 Recitation
LMC.description: Film Screening for Cinema and Digital Culture.

LMC.name: Major Filmmakers
LMC.description: Traces in depth an individual artists career and affords students the opportunity to immerse themselves in the works of an important figure in the world of film.

LMC.name: LMC 3256 Recitation
LMC.description: Film Screening for Major Filmmakers.

LMC.name: Global Cinema
LMC.description: This course examines selected movements styles and trends in world cinema emphasizing how contemporary films global nature affects cultural representation.

LMC.name: LMC 3257 Recitation
LMC.description: Film Screening for Global Cinema.

LMC.name: Documentary Film
LMC.description: This course examines significant movements styles and trends in fact-based film emphasizing its cultural implications and formal strategies.

LMC.name: LMC 3258 Recitation
LMC.description: Film Screening for Documentary Film.

LMC.name: Experimental Film
LMC.description: This course examines the history and trends in experimental film and video emphasizing the relationship to avant-garde art movements.

LMC.name: LMC 3259 Recitation
LMC.description: Experimental FilmRecitation.

LMC.name: Performance Studies
LMC.description: An examination of cultural theories of performance and their application to the analysis of specific performative events.

LMC.name: Music, Culture, and Society
LMC.description: Origins and development of contemporary popular music including rock trap hip-hop and other emerging and established forms.

LMC.name: Science, Technology, and Ideology
LMC.description: Examines specific scientific philosophical and literary/cultural texts in order to determine the role ideology plays in the construction of culture especially scientific and technological culture.

LMC.name: Science, Technology, and Gender
LMC.description: Examines specific philosophical scientific and cultural texts to determine the role that gender has played in the scientific and technological knowledge currently and historically.

LMC.name: Science, Technology, and Race
LMC.description: Examines specific historical and contemporary construction of race within the prevailing scientific theories and ideologies in order to determine the role played by race in scientific and technological culture.

LMC.name: Environmentalism and Ecocriticism
LMC.description: Surveys the emergence of ecocriticism as an analytical framework for interpreting the verbal and visual rhetorics of environmentalism in both western and nonwestern cultures.

LMC.name: The Rhetoric of Scientific Inquiry
LMC.description: This course takes as its subject the ways in which argumentative and persuasive discourse is used to create and disseminate scientific knowledge.

LMC.name: Technologies of Representation
LMC.description: Explores historical cultural and theoretical issues related by technologies of representation including written spoken and gestural languages print painting and illustration still and moving photography recorded sound and computer mediated communications and interactive digital media.

LMC.name: Science, Technology, and Postcolonialism
LMC.description: Studies in the development of Postcolonial literary theory and historiography in order to analyze the interdependent discourses and practices of post-Enlightenment science/technology and European imperialism.

LMC.name: Biomedicine and Culture
LMC.description: Discuss the history of biology and medicine popular representations of health disease and the medical establishment and the cultural implications of medical imaging technologies.

LMC.name: Film and/as Technology
LMC.description: Examines the development of film technology and the implications of that technology for cinemas treatment of technology.

LMC.name: LMC 3352 Recitation
LMC.description: Film Screening for Film And/As Technology.

LMC.name: Graphic and Visual Design
LMC.description: Introduction to fundamentals of graphic and visual design of print and digital media. Familiarity with use of the World Wide Web page layout and computer graphic software recommended.

LMC.name: Technical Communication, Theory and Practice
LMC.description: This course introduces students to workplace document genres to develop visual and verbal skills in critical analysis and document development.

LMC.name: Social Media
LMC.description: Students learn the cultural history theory and practice of social media in a variety of settings and its impact on personal professional and political life.

LMC.name: Media, Culture, and Society
LMC.description: Examines the transformative impact of various kinds of media on culture politics communication and education.

LMC.name: Video Production
LMC.description: An introduction to video production including basic skills in storyboarding scripting filming editing and sound.

LMC.name: Advanced Video Production
LMC.description: This production course teaches students to create visually compelling and emotionally powerful images through shot design and the use of lights cameras and prime lenses.

LMC.name: The Rhetoric of Technical Narratives
LMC.description: Focuses on the rhetorical problems posed by such narrative documents as technical proposals recommendations reports grant proposals and marketing studies. Emphasis on document design graphics navigation systems and editing.

LMC.name: The Rhetoric of Nonlinear Documents
LMC.description: Focuses on the rhetorical problems posed by hypertext documents. Emphasis in designing for multiple audiences page and document design and navigation in a nonlinear environment.

LMC.name: The Rhetoric of Visual Communication
LMC.description: Focuses on contexts audiences arguements and design in creating and critiquing visuals. Emphasizes topics such as information design technical visuals and photography.

LMC.name: Communicating Science and Technology to the Public
LMC.description: Examines both the theoretical and practical issues involved in communicating scientific and/or technological material to a variety of lay audiences.

LMC.name: Technical Communication Approaches
LMC.description: Part of a multi-semester sequence that students take in tandem with major-specific classes to develop professional written visual oral and analytic strategies.

LMC.name: Technical Communication Strategies
LMC.description: Part of a multi-semester sequence that students take in tandem with major-specific classes to develop professional written visual oral and analytic strategies.

LMC.name: Ancient and Medieval Literature and Culture
LMC.description: Introduction to Greece Rome and Medieval Europe through an examination of one or a few major culture conflicts expressed in the literary genres and periods.

LMC.name: Renaissance Literature and Culture
LMC.description: An examination of literature and culture from 1450 to 1650 with an emphasis on both major achievements and divergent voices.

LMC.name: Enlightenment and Culture
LMC.description: Examines the nature of the age from an intial boldness optimism and faith in reason to a recognition of its limits.

LMC.name: American Literature & Culture
LMC.description: Introduces students to American literature and culture broadly construed examining foundational works of critical and historical significance.

LMC.name: British and Continental Romanticism
LMC.description: Examines British and Continental Romanticism as it appeared during the latter part of the eighteenth century and the first half of the nineteenth century.

LMC.name: Victorian Literature and Culture
LMC.description: Investigates the period 1830 - 1901 in English literature and culture focusing on how that period defined key questions especially ones about human nature society and the relation of religion to science.

LMC.name: Literary and Cultural Modernism
LMC.description: A partial investigation of the aesthetic ferment that characterizes English-language cultural production from the turn of the century to the end of World War II.

LMC.name: Literary and Cultural Postmodernism
LMC.description: A survey of major themes representational techniques and social and cultural concerns of postmodern art and literature.

LMC.name: Contemporary Issues in Literature & Culture
LMC.description: This course will cover a range of possible critical areas of global concern in contemporary literature and culture. Focus will vary each semester.

LMC.name: Theatre Production III: Management
LMC.description: In this hands-on course students will create and execute a publicity campaign and operate the box office for DramaTech Theatre productions.

LMC.name: Theatre Production IV: Acting
LMC.description: This course providess students an opportunity to perform onstage in a production at DramaTech Theatre. Auditions are required.

LMC.name: Principles of Information Design
LMC.description: Presents principles and practices guiding the development of emerging digital genres. Emphasis on maximizing the affordances of the computer in organizing and communicating complex information.

LMC.name: Principles of Interaction Design
LMC.description: Examines principles of design for shaping the procedural and participatory affordances of digital environments emphasizing the role of cultural context and media transitions.

LMC.name: Special Topics
LMC.description: Special Topics.

LMC.name: Senior Seminar in Literature, Media, and Communication
LMC.description: Capstone seminar that asks majors to draw upon their training to engage in closer analysis research and/or production in topical area. Topic varies by instructor.

LMC.name: Senior Thesis
LMC.description: Preparation for and writing of a thesis through faculty-directed independent study.

LMC.name: Poetry and Poetics II
LMC.description: Advanced study of the traditions of poetic theory and practice with a special emphasis on processes of poetic conception and revision.

LMC.name: Contemporary Issues in Professional Communication
LMC.description: Intended primarily for students planning careers in professional communication this course will alternate among a number of issues including property law integrating print and electronic media and cultural studies of corporate environments.

LMC.name: Seminar in Film Studies
LMC.description: An in-depth investigation of a major movement theory period or technological development in film studies.

LMC.name: LMC 4500 Recitation
LMC.description: Film Screening for Seminar in Film.

LMC.name: Performance Practicum
LMC.description: Practical experience and theoretical investigations in theatre and performance making including acting directing designing playwriting performance art performance and new media.

LMC.name: Research Assistantship
LMC.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

LMC.name: Undergraduate Research
LMC.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

LMC.name: Undergraduate Research Proposal Writing
LMC.description: This course is intended to guide undergraduate students from all disciplines through the stages of writing a proposal for their research option project and thesis.

LMC.name: Undergraduate Research Thesis Writing
LMC.description: This course is intended to guide undergraduate students from all disciplines through the stages of writing their undergraduate thesis.

LMC.name: Game Studio
LMC.description: Project-based course in designing and implementing video games.

LMC.name: Interactive Narrative
LMC.description: Examines significant examples of this emerging genre including its roots ini experimental uses of older media and engages students in creating their own interactive narrative.

LMC.name: Games Design as a Cultural Practice
LMC.description: Emphasis is on the design elements common to games and the expressive possibilities and cultural concerns specific to digital games.

LMC.name: Experimental Digital Art
LMC.description: Provides students with key conceptual formal aesthetic and technical elements needed in creating artifacts in areas ranging from augmented and mixed reality to scientific visualization.

LMC.name: Game AI
LMC.description: Examines expressive possibilities of artificial intelligence techniques in computer games.

LMC.name: Mixed Reality Experience Design
LMC.description: Project-based course in designing implementing experiences using the technologies of Augmented Mixed and Virtual Reality. Credit not awarded for both LMC4733 and CS4770/6770/LMC6340.

LMC.name: Special Topics
LMC.description: Topic of current interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

LMC.name: Special Topics
LMC.description: Topics of current interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

LMC.name: Special Topics
LMC.description: Topics of interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

LMC.name: Special Topics
LMC.description: Topics of interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

LMC.name: Internship
LMC.description: Offers students a workplace-based learning experience that stresses application of principles and skills gained in other STAC classes.

LMC.name: Edu Applications New
LMC.description: This course introduces students to a variety of perspectives on learning as they apply to work in educational technology. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6213 and LCC 6213.

LMC.name: Issues in Media Studies
LMC.description: This course focuses on the study of mass media from historical theoretical and cultural perspectives. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6215 and LCC 6215.

LMC.name: The Computer as an "Expressive Medium"
LMC.description: Explores the development of the representational power of the computer and the interplay between digital technology and culture. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6310 and LCC 6310.

LMC.name: Visual Culture and Design
LMC.description: Explores visual media through a mutually instructive and integrated interplay between critical analyses and the creation of digital artifacts. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6311 and LCC 6311.

LMC.name: Design, Technology & Representation
LMC.description: Explores historical cultural and theoretical issues raised by technologies of representation through critical analyses and the creation of digital artifacts. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6312 and LCC 6312.

LMC.name: Principles of Interaction Design
LMC.description: Explores visual media through a mutually instructive and integrated interplay between critical analyses and the creation of digital artifacts. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6313 and LCC 6313.

LMC.name: Design of Networked Media
LMC.description: Issues in hypertextual and multimedia design in networked environments including the World Wide Web interactive television and wireless applications. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6314 and LCC 6314.

LMC.name: Product Production
LMC.description: Focuses on defining user and client needs analysis of competing products budgeting scheduling and management of the production process and the design of the testing process. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6315 and LCC 6315.

LMC.name: Historical Approaches to Digital Media
LMC.description: Examines digital media in the context of earlier media such as handwriting and printing as well as photography radio film and television. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6316 and LCC 6316.

LMC.name: Interactive Narrative/Fiction
LMC.description: Students create interactive fictions in a variety of formats including intersecting story worlds interactive characters simulations and replay worlds. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6317 and LCC 6317 LMC6317 and LCC 4720 or LMC6317 and LMC4720.

LMC.name: Experimental Media
LMC.description: Students will develop the critical intellectual and creative tools necessary to understand work with and reimagine design at the developmental stages of emerging technologies. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6318 and LCC 6318.

LMC.name: Intellectural Property Policy and Law
LMC.description: Students examine constitutionally informed policy and pragmatic legal issues in intellectual property law focusing on the effects of power structures and information digitization. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6319 and LCC 6319.

LMC.name: Globalization and New Media
LMC.description: Historical and theoretical approach to the connections between modes of global integration and modes of representing information. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6320 and LCC 6320.

LMC.name: Architecture of Responsive Spaces
LMC.description: Historical and theoretical approach to the connections between modes of global integration and modes of representing information. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6321 and LCC 6321.

LMC.name: Global Intellectual Property Policy and Law
LMC.description: This course requires that students gain facility with intellectual property statutory and treaty law and understand US and global policies that affect power and access.

LMC.name: Game Design and Analysis
LMC.description: Focused topics in the theory and practice of game design theory and analysis including issues of creation and reception such as a single sub-genre procedural technique or media tradition. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6325 and LCC 6325 LMC6325 and LCC 4725 or LMC6325 and LMC4725.

LMC.name: Expressive Virtual Space
LMC.description: Practical and theoretical investigation of virtual space in real-time 3D environments with a focus on meditation and functionality. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6330 and LCC 6330.

LMC.name: Mixed Reality Experience Design
LMC.description: This course introduces students to the design of digital experienced for education and entertainment using Augmented Reality Tangible Computing or other forms of Mixed Reality. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6340 and LCC 6340/LMC4733/CS6770/4770.

LMC.name: The spatial construction of meaning: Design formulation and design cognition
LMC.description: Study of the way in which space is manipulated to construct meaning in design formulation. Emphasis on logical structure geometry and experiential correlates. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6350 and LCC 6350.

LMC.name: Global Ethnographies and Communication Practices
LMC.description: This course employs ethnographic methods to examine how the creation of visual textual and digita artifacts can be understood as practices of intercultural communication.

LMC.name: Global Science Fiction
LMC.description: Explores how authors and critics across the globe use science fiction to communicate experiences with science and technology across centuries continents and cultures.

LMC.name: Literary and Cultural Theory
LMC.description: Concentration on a single literary or cultural theorist and/or major school of literary or cultural theory including among others Materialist Feminist Structuralist Post-Structuralistm Cultural Studies.

LMC.name: Global Cinema
LMC.description: This course examines significant movements styles and trends in world cinema with an emphasis on how the global nature of contemporary film affects cultural representation.

LMC.name: Discovery & Invention
LMC.description: Required course for all DM majors. The purpose of this course is to give students a suite of methods they can use in professional settings to discover opportunities for inventive new computational products and services. It complements the design and production skills developed in 6310 and 6313 with applied research skills. For students in the MS DM and MS HCI programs it will also help them in the development of their MS proposals. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6399 and LCC 6399.

LMC.name: Project Studio
LMC.description: This course offers students the opportunity to work on focused research within existing long-term projects of the New Media(NM) Center.

LMC.name: STS Core Seminar
LMC.description: This survey course covers key works Science Technology  Society and guest lectures introduce students to faculty doing STS-related research across the Ivan Allen College. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6743 and LCC 6743 LMC6743 and HTS6743 or LMC6743 and PUBP6743.

LMC.name: Social Justice, Critical Theory, and Philosophy of Design
LMC.description: Focuses on social justice from a Science Technology and Society(STS) point of view that is informed by critical theory and philosophy of design. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6748 and LCC 6748 or LMC6748 and PUBP6748.

LMC.name: Feminist theory and STS
LMC.description: This course is an advanced science technology and society (STS) seminar in feminist theory. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6749 and LCC 6749 or LMC6749 and PUBP6749.

LMC.name: Human-Computer Interaction Professional Preparation and Practice
LMC.description: Preparation for a professional career in HCI. Hands-on workshops in resume and portfolio building interviewing public speaking team work. HCI career choices and trajectories.

LMC.name: Mixed Reality Design
LMC.description: This course introduces students to mixed reality design and prototyping with a focus on Augmented Reality. Students cannot receive credit for LMC6770 and CS4770.

LMC.name: Digital Media Master's Project
LMC.description: Final project course in Digital Media.

LMC.name: HCI Master's Project
LMC.description: Final project for students completing a Human-Computer Interaction masters degree in the Digital Media track. Repeatable for multi-semester projects.

LMC.name: Digital Media Master's Thesis
LMC.description: Final Thesis course in Digital Media.

LMC.name: PhD Qualifying Prep
LMC.description: Preparation for Ph.D. Qualifying exam.

LMC.name: Proseminar in Media Theory
LMC.description: Key traditions of media theory that contribute to the study of Digital Media. Students cannot receive credit for LMC8000 and LCC 8000.

LMC.name: Proseminar in Digital Media Studies
LMC.description: Advanced work in production and critique of new media forms. Students cannot receive credit for LMC8001 and LCC 8001.

LMC.name: Special Topics
LMC.description: Topic of current interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

LMC.name: Special Topics in Digital Media
LMC.description: Special Topics in Digital Media.

LMC.name: Advanced Issues in Interactive Narrative
LMC.description: Advanced Issues in Interactive Narrative.

LMC.name: Special Topics in Game Design and Analysis
LMC.description: Advanced topics in the theory and practice of game design theory and analysis including creation reception procedural technique and tradition.

LMC.name: Special Topics in Technologies of Representation
LMC.description: Special Topics in Technologies of Representation.

LMC.name: Special Problems in Human-Computer Interaction
LMC.description: Small-group of individual investigation of advanced topics in human-computer interaction. Guided study and research.

LMC.name: Special Problems in Information Design and Technology
LMC.description: An independent study course.

LMC.name: Teaching Assistantship
LMC.description: For graduate students holding teaching assistantships.

LMC.name: Research Assistantship
LMC.description: For graduate students holding research assistantships.

LMC.name: PhD Doctoral Prep
LMC.description: Doctoral Thesis Prep in Digital Media.

LMC.name: Doctoral dissertation in Digital Media
LMC.description: Doctoral Dissertation.

MGT.name: Legal, Social, Ethical Aspects of Business
MGT.description: Development and function of the law court organization procedure and substantive law in contracts business organizations and agencies. Also exposes social responsibility and ethics in business.

MGT.name: Information Systems and Digital Transformation
MGT.description: How information and information systems support business operations decision-making and differentiation and transform organizations and industries. Hands-on experience with current tools for working with data.

MGT.name: Management Statistics
MGT.description: This is the introduction to basic statistics for management students.

MGT.name: Quantitative Analysis for Business
MGT.description: This course focuses on the problem-solving and decision-making processes that use quantitative management science concepts and techniques. Credit will not be awarded for both MGT2255 and MGT 2251.

MGT.name: Management Internship
MGT.description: Recognition for a paid full or part time employment experience that is relevant to a students management education.

MGT.name: Internship and Independent Study
MGT.description: Independent study conducted for one student under the guidance of a faculty member in association with an unpaid internship.

MGT.name: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
MGT.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

MGT.name: Undergraduate Research
MGT.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

MGT.name: Special Topics
MGT.description: Permits a group of students and a professor to pursue areas of management not extensively treated in any other course.

MGT.name: Special Problems
MGT.description: Independent study conducted for one student under the guidance of a faculty member.

MGT.name: Special Problems
MGT.description: Independent study conducted for one student under the guidance of a faculty member.

MGT.name: Special Problems
MGT.description: Independent study conducted for one student under the guidance of a faculty member.

MGT.name: Accounting for Decision Making
MGT.description: A foundation course in measuring and reporting the financial performance and status of the firm as well as basic concepts in cost and managerial accounting. No credit allowed for MGT majors. No credit allowed for MGT3000 and ACCT2101.  Credit not allowed for MGT3000 and ACCT2102.

MGT.name: Financial Management
MGT.description: An introduction to finance. Topics include time value of money capital budgeting risk and return capital structure dividend policy and working capital management. No credit allowed for MGT3062 and MGT3078.

MGT.name: Security Valuation
MGT.description: The valuation of securities using fundamental and technical analysis. Topics include DCF valuation price multiples free cash flow and the construction of quantitative trading models.

MGT.name: Investments
MGT.description: Introduction to the securities markets and a study of the theory and practice of security analysis and portfolio management as applied to stocks and bonds. Credit not allowed for MGT3076 and MGT3078.

MGT.name: Finance and Investments
MGT.description: An introduction to finance and to the securities markets. Topics include time value of money risk and return capital budgeting security analysis and portfolio management of stocks bonds and derivatives. No credit allowed for MGT majors. Credit not allowed for MGT3078 and MGT3062.  Credit not allowed for MGT3078 and MGT3076.

MGT.name: Management of Financial Institutions
MGT.description: Introduction to the various risks faced by financial institutions and a detailed analysis of the tools used to manage these risks.

MGT.name: Fundamentals of Real Estate Development
MGT.description: An overview of the real estate development process from concept through design feasibility financing construction marketing management and ultimate sale or long term financing.

MGT.name: Derivative Securities
MGT.description: An introduction to options futures and swaps is provided. Concepts of arbitrage index trading and portfolio insurance are discussed.

MGT.name: Organizational Behavior
MGT.description: Introduction to how the behavior of individuals groups and organizations affects organizational effectiveness.  Credit not allowed for both MGT3101 and 3150.

MGT.name: Managing Human Resources within a Regulatory Environment
MGT.description: Analysis of various frameworks for understanding the social regulatory environments of human resources management and how they influence management decision making.

MGT.name: Leadership in a Changing Environment
MGT.description: The course focuses on the leadership challenges posed by recent changes in the business environment and on the skills needed to adapt to those changes.

MGT.name: Cross-cultural Management
MGT.description: This course develops students global awareness to better understand and cope with the issues and challenges that managers face when working across international boundaries.

MGT.name: Principles of Management
MGT.description: Course explores functions of management planning organizing staffing leading and controlling.  Lectures case studies and business exercises are used to reinforce principles that are taught.  Credit not allowed for both MGT3150 and MGT3101.

MGT.name: Marketing Management I
MGT.description: The course presents and develops the primary marketing variables that are used in designing an overall marketing program.  A systems approach is taken with the variables managed to optimize overall results.

MGT.name: Marketing Research: Qualitative Aspects
MGT.description: This course covers the fundamentals of the qualitative aspects of marketing research. The course has an applied orientation with application to contemporary issues in marketing.

MGT.name: Pricing Strategy and Analytics
MGT.description: The course introduces the conceptual underpinnings of the price setting process and discusses ways to leverage modern marketing analytic tools/methods to improve pricing decisions.

MGT.name: Social Media Marketing
MGT.description: Explores the use of social media marketing as a fundamental marketing channel for driving customer engagement brand advocacy and enhanced customer loyalty.

MGT.name: Product Planning
MGT.description: Overviews issues inherent in product development and product management. These include product strategy idea generation market development product positioning test marketing launch and brand management.

MGT.name: Operations Management
MGT.description: This course focuses on the issues and techniques relevant to the management of the operations function within an organization emphasizing its strategic significance.

MGT.name: Management of Technology
MGT.description: Focus on managing the design assessment and implementation-change strategy of a firms manufacturing and information-based technological capabilities to improve competitive performance.

MGT.name: Career Development Workshop
MGT.description: This workshop style class focuses on skills and strategies for identifying a career path and conducting a successful job search in the field of management.

MGT.name: Principles of Commerical Law
MGT.description: Course offers an in-depth examination of contracts negotiable instruments and creditor/debtor issues all essential for making informed decisions in commercial and financial business environments.

MGT.name: International Business Law
MGT.description: International Business Law focuses on the legal environment of international trade and private commercial transactions.

MGT.name: Business Ethics
MGT.description: This courses introduces students to ethical aspects of the business decision-making process including theoretical underpinnings of ethics stakeholders and decision-making strategies.

MGT.name: Technology Law and Ethics
MGT.description: This class will examine some of the ethical legal and social issues associated with computers information systems and public and private networks including the Internet.

MGT.name: Legal Aspects of Real Estate
MGT.description: Legal Aspects of Real Estate introduces students to legal considerations in real estate including ownership sale transactions leasing title insurance financing zoning and environmental laws.

MGT.name: Law for Entrepreneurs
MGT.description: This course will focus on legal issues which entrepreneurs face while growing a start-up business from infancy to a publicly held company.

MGT.name: Corporate Governance
MGT.description: This course focuses on the U.S. corporate governance model examining the governance and management of business organizations including board of director and officer responsibility.

MGT.name: Foundations of Strategy
MGT.description: This course covers the basic concepts and frameworks of strategy analysis and strategy formulation. Credit will not be awarded for both MGT3659 and MGT 4195.

MGT.name: International Business
MGT.description: Examines the position of the U.S. in world markets various types of international business transactions and the relationship of business to global economic political-legal and cultural forces.

MGT.name: Advanced Concepts in International Business
MGT.description: Covers significant aspects of international business with a particular focus on the challenges associated with transnational corporations.

MGT.name: Management in the Healthcare Sector
MGT.description: An exploration of the healthcare sector in  its most comprehensive sense analyzing the healthcare system and resulting management issues.

MGT.name: Technology Strategy
MGT.description: Provides understanding of economic and strategic factors that guide firms strategic decisions regarding the generation commercialization protection and adoption of the technological innovations.

MGT.name: Corporate Strategy
MGT.description: Provides frameworks and case studies to understand how companies create value across different businesses.

MGT.name: Spreadsheet Modeling for Business Decision Support
MGT.description: Using advanced spreadsheet capabilities macros and add-ons to create decision support systems for business applications. Not an introductory course.

MGT.name: Analysis of Emerging Technologies
MGT.description: Analysis of emerging technologies and their impacts for firm practice market practice policy and society.  Credit not allowed for both MGT3743 and ME3743 or CS3743.

MGT.name: Managing Product, Service & Technology Development
MGT.description: Analysis of the managerial challenges of the product development process. Credit not allowed for both MGT3744 and ME3744/CS3744.

MGT.name: Business Programming
MGT.description: An introduction to the basic concepts and skills of software programming and their applications to solving business problems.

MGT.name: Business Decisions for Sustainability and Shared Value
MGT.description: The WEF Global Risks Report and UN SDGs are used as frameworks to explore the role of basic human needs in shaping long-term business value.

MGT.name: Business Taxation
MGT.description: Comprehensive survey of federal taxation of business. A focus on tax planning and decision making will extend to the study of the tax code and regulations.

MGT.name: Advanced Managerial Accounting
MGT.description: The course will examine current issues in managerial accounting.

MGT.name: Financial Reporting and Analysis I
MGT.description: Intermediate-level treatment of revenue recognition inventories contracts interest capitalization property and equipment intangibles long-term liabilities and shareholders equity. Significant emphasis on financial analysis.

MGT.name: Financial Reporting and Analysis II
MGT.description: Advanced topics including tax reporting leases pensions foreign currency transactions hedging statement translation and business combinations and consolidations. Significant emphasis in financial analysis.

MGT.name: Financial Analysis and Reporting of Technology Firms
MGT.description: An in-depth look at reporting standards for and the financial characteristics of technology firms with an emphasis on the financial analysis of such firms.

MGT.name: International Accounting
MGT.description: An overview of accounting issues arising from the increased internationalization of business.  Topics include comparative financial reporting among countries and accounting treatments of international transactions.

MGT.name: Auditing and Financial Control Systems
MGT.description: This course covers professional issues surrounding auditing and financial control systems. Topics include management fraud legal liability audit evidence etc.

MGT.name: Advanced Financial Reporting
MGT.description: Financial reporting and accounting for mergers and acquisitions consolidated financial statements international transactions and hedges of exchange-rate fluctuations partnerships and governmental and not-for-profit organizations.  Credit not allowed for both MGT4043 and MGT6043.

MGT.name: Seminar in Advanced Accounting
MGT.description: An intensive treatment of a selection of contemporary accounting topics.  Topical coverage may span subject matter ranging across the fields of auditing systems managerial and tax accounting.

MGT.name: Ethics & Accounting
MGT.description: The course is designed to expose students to issues surrounding accountants professional ethics.  Credit not allowed for both MGT4047 and MGT6047.

MGT.name: Business Analytics
MGT.description: This course teaches the process of transforming data into business insights. It covers the methodologies algorithms issues and challenges related to analyzing business data.

MGT.name: Decision Support and Expert Systems
MGT.description: This course discusses the basic features of decision support systems and expert systems. It covers the development tools and business applications.

MGT.name: Systems Analysis and Design
MGT.description: An introductory course on the development life cycle of business information systems. It covers analysis and design tools and methodology.  Credit not allowed for both MGT4052 and CS4052.

MGT.name: Business Data Communications
MGT.description: Introductory data communication concepts.  Data communication applications in organizations.  Overview of data communication products and services available from a technology consumer perspective.

MGT.name: International Issues in Information Technology Management
MGT.description: An overview of international issues in the Information Technology Management (ITM) area. Topics include offshore software development transborder data flow restrictions and global connectivity issues.

MGT.name: Electronic Commerce
MGT.description: This course examines the business and technical issues related to electronic commerce applications such as the Internet WWW EDI and electronic linkages between trading partners.

MGT.name: Business Process Analysis and Design
MGT.description: Business processes are the mechanisms by which work is organized and performed.  This course covers the analysis of business processes and efficient redesign through technology. Credit will not be awarded for both CS4057 and MGT4057.

MGT.name: Database Management Systems
MGT.description: An introductory course on databases providing hands-on experience with a DBMS. Topics include data modeling relational database design and SQL.

MGT.name: Corporate Restructuring
MGT.description: This course examines the finance economics law and business strategies that underlie major corporate restructuring transactions. Topics include valuation acquisitions divestitures and high-leveraged transactions.

MGT.name: Financial Markets: Trading and Structure
MGT.description: The course focuses on liquidity market structure and trading.  Attention is given to the efficiency of trading systems and the role of intermediaries on market structure issues.

MGT.name: Fixed Income
MGT.description: This course covers the important securites that trade in the fixed income market and the valuation models that are used to price them.

MGT.name: International Finance
MGT.description: Financial management in an international setting.  Topics include foreign exchange markets exchange risk management international portfolio investment and foreign direct investment.

MGT.name: Multinational Financial Management
MGT.description: This course emphasizes decision making for the multimedia firm amidst exchange rate fluctuations differing tax structures across countries and political risk via lectures case-discussion and analysis and project-based learning.

MGT.name: Entrepreneurial Finance
MGT.description: This course has been developed to expand the students understanding and knowledge of the financial aspects of starting funding operating and/or exiting an entrepreneurial venture.  Credit not allowed for both MGT4072 and MGT6086.

MGT.name: Financial Modeling
MGT.description: This course presents tools necessary to build advanced Excel spreadsheets for financial decision-making. The course will include topics such as firm valuation financial statements cost of capital portfolio construction option valuation duration and immunization.

MGT.name: Management Consulting
MGT.description: This course explores being a Management Consultant and will introduce students to consulting frameworks and methods simulate consulting activities and situations using cases.

MGT.name: The Role of Gender, Race and Ethnicity in Organizational Behavior
MGT.description: This course will examine how managers and employees become more effective leaders by understanding the role gender race and ethnicity plays in the life of the organization.  Credit not allowed for both MGT4116 and MGT6116.

MGT.name: Global Workforce Management
MGT.description: This course examines how an organization deploys and manages a global workforce while considering cultural and economic differences across the world.

MGT.name: Leading Teams in Organizations
MGT.description: This course prepares students to be an effective leaders and managers of teams by giving students frameworks to implement and diagnose effective team processes.

MGT.name: Business Forecasting
MGT.description: The course covers statistical tools to forecast using the past behavior of data. Topics include moving average and autoregressive models trends cycles and volatility.

MGT.name: Strategic Quality Management and Competitiveness
MGT.description: This course examines the philosophy and techniques of strategic quality management (e.g. cycle time mgt. learning organizations quality control) as means to promote individual productivity and improve organizational competitiveness.

MGT.name: The Entrepreneurship Forum
MGT.description: This course provides an understanding of the entrepreneurial process explores the role of the entrepreneur and identifies the critical issues in starting ventures and working in entrepreneurial organizations.

MGT.name: Impact Speaker Series Forum
MGT.description: With the a speaker series as an integral component the class explores the competencies and aspects of making an impact.  Through speakers articles and case studies it presents examples for review and insights.

MGT.name: Servant Leadership, Values & Systems
MGT.description: An exploration of the nature and integration of inidividual and organizational values systemic thinking and the concept of servant leadership.  Learning occurs through case studies simulations readings personal reflection and team activities.

MGT.name: Social Enterprise and Entrepreneurship
MGT.description: Social Entrepreneurship applies innovative solutions to the worlds pressing social problems by having students utilize leadership and managerial skills to address major challenges.

MGT.name: Strategy Consulting Practicum
MGT.description: Provides experiential learning in strategy processes of analysis design and execution. Emphasis on issues currently confronted by major corporations.

MGT.name: Integrative Management Experience
MGT.description: Provides understanding of strategy implementation and the integration of different functional areas of the firm using lectures cases and a Capstone simulation. Credit will not be awared for both MGT4220 and MGT 4195.

MGT.name: Personal Selling and Sales Management
MGT.description: Students will obtain an understanding of the management of the sales function.  The importance of the marketing-sales interface will be stressed.

MGT.name: Strategic Brand Management
MGT.description: This course teaches undergraduate students about the importance of brands and makes them knowledgeable about and able to apply instruments to create monitor and manage brands.

MGT.name: Business-to-Business Marketing
MGT.description: This course studies the marketing of products and services for resale for use in producing other goods and services and for the operations of an enterprise.

MGT.name: Strategic Marketing
MGT.description: Students will obtain an understanding of strategic marketing development and alternatives. Analysis and implementation through functional marketing strategies will be stressed.

MGT.name: Advertising & Promotion: Integrated Marketing Communications
MGT.description: This course is designed to focus on the primary marketing of communication through advertising and promotion implemented with an integrated approach.  Strategic and tactical dimensions are covered for both traditional media such as broadcast print out-of-home and direct as well as new media including the internet mobile and other trends in the industry.

MGT.name: Services Marketing
MGT.description: Explores how many of the traditional marketing models can be adapted to the marketing of services as well as introducing entirely new concepts and frameworks specifically applicable to services and services marketing.

MGT.name: Digital Marketing
MGT.description: This course explores the various components of the digital channel including social mobile and search engine marketing to understand how to implement an effective digital marketing strategy.

MGT.name: Consumer Behavior
MGT.description: An applied course that provides a basic understanding of the behavioral science concepts to explain the behavior of consumers in the marketplace.

MGT.name: Database and CRM Strategy
MGT.description: Provides an understanding of analytic techniques and computer models in analyzing customer-centric data and developing customer relationship (CRM) strategy.

MGT.name: International Marketing
MGT.description: Students will obtain an understanding of marketing across national borders and cultures.  The differences and similarities throughout the marketing functions are explored.

MGT.name: Management of Healthcare Operations
MGT.description: Explore the roles of operations management practices and health information technologies in addressing the challenges in the healthcare enterprise and harnessing opportunities for transforming it.

MGT.name: Marketing Practicum
MGT.description: This project based course provides practical experience addressing strategic marketing opportunities and helps develop high value skills for critically analyzing problems and providing tractable solutions.

MGT.name: Operations Planning and Control
MGT.description: The management of material flows within an enterprise will be covered by tracking the evolution of operational planning and execution systems through the enterprise resource planning (ERP) framework.

MGT.name: Operations Strategy
MGT.description: This course provides knowledge about developing implementing and evaluating operations strategy.  It stresses the relationships between the operations and other functions of the organization.

MGT.name: Global Operations and Logistics
MGT.description: This course is designed to present issues critical to the globalization of operations and addresses strategic and tactical issues pertaining to an organizations global operations and supply chain activities.

MGT.name: Quality Control and Improvement
MGT.description: This course focuses on statistical process control acceptance sampling robust design and other general methodologies for quality improvement.

MGT.name: Service Operations Management
MGT.description: This course analyzes operational performance for the service and for service-support functions of manufacturers. Industries include information services health care parking transportation distribution and retail.

MGT.name: Revenue Analytics
MGT.description: This course examines how an organization deploys and manages model and data driven pricing techniques to maximize revenues.

MGT.name: Sustainable Business Consulting Practicum
MGT.description: Learn consulting skills and apply these to a sustainability issue for a client organization.  Instructors and coaches offer expertise in corporate sustainability and management consulting.

MGT.name: Supply Chain Modeling
MGT.description: The objective of this course is to provide students with tools and models for matching supply and demand in the most cost effective way.

MGT.name: Project Management
MGT.description: Concepts techniques and tools from the project management body of knowledge covering initiating planning controlling executing and closing projects. Includes agile techniques and certification preparation. Credit will not be awarded for both MGT4450 and MGT6450.

MGT.name: Management Internship
MGT.description: Recognition for a paid full or part time employment experience that is relevant to a students management education.

MGT.name: Internship and Independent Study
MGT.description: Independent study conducted for one student under the guidance of a faculty member in association with an unpaid internship.

MGT.name: Law, Management, and Economics
MGT.description: Interrelationships among law economics and management.  Focuses on the legal and economic aspects of management decisions.

MGT.name: Integrative Management Analysis
MGT.description: Integrates the functional areas of management economics and the external environment in which businesses operate.  The course is designed to broaden the students perspective on management.

MGT.name: Entrepreneurship
MGT.description: Provides students with an understanding of the process of establishing a technology-based venture. Students learn how to evaluate market opportunities conduct feasibility studies create venture teams and write business plans.

MGT.name: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
MGT.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

MGT.name: Undergraduate Research
MGT.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

MGT.name: Information Security Strategies and Policy
MGT.description: Information security vulnerabilities and risks legal cost privacy and technology constraints derivation of strategies technical and procedural means of achieving desired ends. Credit will not be awarded for both MGT4725 and MGT6725 or CS6725 or CS4725 or PUBP4725 or PUBP6725.

MGT.name: Privacy, Technology, Policy, and Law
MGT.description: This course takes a multi-disciplinary approach to privacy a topic of great interest in the technology policy ethics law and business realms. Credit will not be awarded for both MGT4726 and MGT6726 or CS4726 or CS6726 or PUBP4726 or PUBP6726.

MGT.name: Integrative Management Development-Project Preparation
MGT.description: Individual and group-based experiential learning activities to develop integrated human system management skills that prepare students for more successful capstone collaboration and learning.  Credit not allowed for both MGT4741 and CS4741 or ME4741.

MGT.name: Integrated Technology and Management Capstone Project
MGT.description: Project-based course where students in the Technology and Management Program will work in inter-disciplinary teams on projects provided by corporate affiliates.  Credit not allowed for both MGT4742 and CS4742 or ME4742.

MGT.name: Special Topics in Industrial Management
MGT.description: Permits a group of students and a professor to pursue areas of management not extensively treated in any other course.

MGT.name: Special Topics in Management
MGT.description: Permits a group of students and a professor to pursue areas of management not extensively treated in other courses.
